I am looking back at the records of the Commons debate, Hansard of April 30, 1992, page 9920. I am looking at a very direct question that was put to the minister responsible for Canada Post by my colleague from Essex-Kent who said to the minister very specifically:
Earlier today the minister introduced measures to allow employees of Canada Post to buy shares in the Crown corporation.
Will the minister take this opportunity to admit to Canadians that he was embarking on the first steps of privatization of Canada Post?
June 18, 1992

That is exactly the point made previously, Madam Speaker.
I would like to read the reply from the Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons, the minister responsible for Canada Post. He said:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know why I would admit that. It would not be
the truth if I were to do that.
He made it quite clear that this bill was not intended as a step toward privatization and yet we have a member of the government sitting on the other side of the House not 10 minutes ago, in response to a comment from this side of the House that this is the first step toward privatization saying "that's right".
Is it any wonder that Canadians have a lot of trouble trusting this government? When the minister in April said "that is wrong, that would not be the truth, if I were to admit we were taking the first steps toward privatization" and now in the heat of June another member of that same government sits there and says that that is exactly what the government is doing.
If Canadians right here in this Chamber can hear completely opposite stories from two members of the same government, is there any wonder that the popularity level of the Prime Minister and his government is at the stage it is? Is it any wonder that Canadians can hardly wait to get rid of this government? Really, is it any wonder that they hold the government and this institution in such disrespect when from that side of the House we hear contradictory statements constantly. We hear denials one day and the accusations become reality weeks or months later.
The member opposite seems to want to debate the free trade agreement. I would love to debate the free trade agreement, the past one and the future one, and point out all the failings of that agreement if he would have the courtesy to put that item on the agenda of the House rather than trying to interrupt a member who has some important issues and points to say on behalf of her constituents on the bill that is before the House on Canada Post.
As well, I note today that the Liberal Party is alone in fighting against this abomination of a bill, the first step in getting rid of a service that has served this country well since Confederation. The socialists are not here. The
Government Orders
NDP, which speaks out against privatization, which would like the state to own and operate everything, is not here to say one word in defence of Canada Post. It is not here to say one word in defence of maintaining in the public domain an essential public service to a country like Canada that is so far and so widespread, with such a scattered population, that the ability to communicate with one another is fundamental to national unity. It is fundamental to our sense of being Canadian.
The Liberals stand alone here today defending the continuation of that service in the public domain and in the public interest, not in the interest of profits.
I want to make a few points about the treatment of employees in Canada Post. The minister has made the point that this is to try and get employees more involved in Canada Post, to let them feel a little more a part of the corporation and to make them a little more productive.
There are many ways in which Canada Post has shown that it does not care one whit for its employees. Its treatment of women is abominable. In the interests of profits it is contracting out work, putting on more part-time people, taking people who worked for it for a decade or more and suddenly putting them back on night shift.
It is entirely refusing to pay women equal pay for work of equal value. It has taken provisions out its contract that requires its contractors to pay women decent wages. It talks about shared decision making. Its day to day operations are a total denial of any respect for its employees or any attempt to let them feel proud of their work and to feel that they have a employer that they can work in partnership with.
Labour relations at the post office are no secret to anybody in this country. They are in an abysmal state. One can only question them since this bill before us is a shell. It gives us absolutely no details. It tells us not one thing about what is really going to happen here, what the shares are going to be worth, what they are going to mean to employees or which employees are going to be able to buy them. One can only speculate that if there is any value to the shares at all, they will go to senior managers and if there is no value to the shares at all, then the employees at the lower level might have some access to them.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
I want to go back and let people recall the privatization of Air Canada. There is a pattern to privatization. Senior managers and corporations always love to push for privatization because they always seem to manage to set up privatization deals that give them a good hunk of shares, a good stake in the company which means the loss of jobs and less income for those who actually do the work that produces the profits.
I want to go back to Air Canada because I remember with great chagrin the night I heard Claude Taylor, just before the privatization of Air Canada, on Cross Country Check-Up saying that if only he were free of all these fetters of government ownership, of government direction, he could run Air Canada much better, much more profitably. I suspect that the privatization of Air Canada benefited Claude Taylor and a lot of other senior executives in Air Canada.
It has meant the loss of thousands of jobs. It has meant the loss of service to northern and remote communities in this country. It has meant increased costs. It has meant reduced service and it is a classic demonstration of why privatization in an industry like transportation or communication, that is so essential to keeping this country together, is not in the public interest.
The public interest is something that does not seem to matter a lot to this government or to Canada Post.
I can only mention small postal outlets in my riding, 10 to 20 feet from a senior citizens' building, being closed down and moved a mile away. These older people who are trying to live on their own, 190 of them in one apartment building, who want to be able to communicate with family and friends who have now moved all over Canada, cannot even get out in the winter to mail a letter, to pick up some stamps, to mail a parcel at Christmas time.
This is happening all over my riding. I have in my riding the second highest proportion of seniors in the country and so I worry about these things. I wish Canada Post worried about people who have to rely on the mail simply to remain in touch with their loved ones. It does not. It does not even make sensible decisions.
I have a branch of the post office that has been out on Richmond Road in Ottawa West for many years, since I moved out to that part of the city. Lo and behold, 100 feet down the road it opened up a private outlet. What does that mean? Better service to me? No. Now I have to go to two places.
Our time is short today but the bottom line is we want a postal service that delivers service to Canadians, one whose purpose is not profits, not exploitation of its workers but service to Canadians. We want the honest truth for once from this government on its intentions. Do not give us a shell of a bill that does not tell us what its real plans are.

Madam Speaker, I too want to participate in the debate on Bill C-73. As I do, let me say the speech by my colleague, the hon. member for Ottawa West, was an absolutely outstanding speech because it embraced what is important about Canada Post for the whole country.
The member pointed out that Canada Post is not only an essential ingredient to nation building, holding the country together in so far as rural Canada is concerned, but is important for those citizens who have made their contribution to this country, those senior citizens, particularly in urban Canada, who now find for economic reasons that they must live in senior citizens' complexes. Canada Post is a way of staying in touch with their loved ones no matter where they have gone.
I thought the member demonstrated why Canada Post is an ingredient of national unity at a time when the country is being tested, when the stresses and strains on the fabric of this nation are more pronounced than perhaps at any other time in our history.
As my colleague from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception said a few moments ago, thousands of people gathered in various communities of Newfoundland and perhaps elsewhere in this country, demanding that their voices be heard, demanding that there be an opportunity for their voices to echo across this Chamber, demanding that their fears, their anger, their frustrations and their hopes be reflected in the voices of their members of this place by way of an emergency debate in the case of Newfoundland on the fishery.

Even as this place cannot find the time to allow that voice to be heard, in the dying days of the session, as this place gets ready to close, perhaps until September, even as we deny that voice a chance to be heard in this place, what does the government do with those precious few remaining hours that are left for the elected representatives of the people to meet and to discuss and to debate and to exchange ideas? What does it do with those remaining minutes? It puts forward this bill, Bill C-73, a blank cheque, a loaded gun pointed right at the head of Canada Post, at the postal service, and I put the emphasis on service.
It is a bill, it is a piece of enabling legislation. It transfers to a minister unchecked, undefined and unbridled powers to do with the post office as he sees fit.
What are we being asked to do with this bill? We are being asked to transfer in a blind arrangement the future of the post office and the role the post office plays in Canadian society into the hands of a minister who will not share with Parliament what he intends to do with that power being transferred to him.
If you look at the bill it does not tell us what the value of the shares are going to be in privatization. It does not tell us what the number of shares are going to be in privatization. It does not tell us the net worth of the corporation. It does not tell us that if employees can buy shares how they shall be defined. It does not tell us the amount of shares every individual employee will be allowed to purchase. It tells us nothing save that the government intends to privatize the post office and it would like Parliament, with blinders on, completely blind and disoriented and confused, to transfer authority to the minister and that the minister functioning in the back room with his advisors will make all the decisions.
We are being interrupted by a greater power.

A message was delivered by the Gentleman Usher of the Black Rod as follows:
Government Orders
Madam Speaker, the Honourable Deputy to His Excellency the Governor General desires the immediate attendance of this honourable House in the Chamber of the honourable Senate.
Accordingly, Madam Speaker with the House went up to the Senate Chamber.
And being returned:

["Unfortunately I must interrupt the hon. member and ask him to show me indulgence at this time. I promise I will recognize him later.\nIt being five o'clock p.m., pursuant to Standing Order 30(6), the House will now proceed to the consideration of Private Members' Business as listed on today's Order Paper."]

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I have the honour to inform the House that when the House went up to the Senate Chamber, the Deputy Governor General was pleased to give, in Her Majesty's name, the Royal Assent to the following bills:
Bill C-21, an act relating to the accounting of certain payments for the servicing and reduction of the debt of Canada-Chapter 18.
Bill C-56, an act respecting the control of government expenditures-Chapter 19.
Bill C-36, an act respecting corrections and the conditional release and detention of offenders and to establish the office of Correctional Investigator-Chapter 20.
Bill C-78, an act to amend certain acts with respect to persons with disabilities-Chapter 21.
Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and other acts in consequence thereof-Chapter 22.
Bill C-59, an act to amend the National Parks Act-Chapter 23.
Bill C-84, an act to amend the Civilian War Pensions and Allowances Act, the War Veterans Allowance Act and the Pension Act and to amend other acts in consequence thereof-Chapter 24.
Bill C-67, an act to suspend the operation of the Electoral Boundaries Readjustment Act-Chapter 25.

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Andre that Bill C-73, an act to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope; and the amendment of Mr. Boudria (p.10744).

Madam Speaker, as I was saying before we were interrupted by the requirements of the Governor General, this bill that is being proposed by the government in the dying minutes and hours and days of this session of Parliament before we adjourn for the summer break is a blank cheque. The government is asking for a blank cheque. The minister in charge of the post office is asking for a loaded gun.

June 18, 1992
Private Members' Business
He is asking for the authority to dramatically alter the size, shape and purpose of Canada's post office. He is asking for the authority and enabling legislation that will allow him to do it behind closed doors in consultation with senior managers of the post office and in consultation with senior bureaucrats. However, there will be no consultation with the people of Canada and no consultation with the elected members of the House of Commons. That is why I object to the bill.
If the government has a plan to reshape the post office, to change the post office and to alter the post office, then tell us what it is. Do not ask for authority to tinker or to alter or to make unrecognizable Canada's post office without telling us how you intend to do it, tell us up front. However, the government will not do that.
One of my colleagues, the member for Bonavista- Trinity-Conception suggested that this is nothing but a Trojan horse. This is a plan to privatize the post office, to break it down, to turn it over to the private sector and to run it on the same principle as McDonald's sells hamburgers.
The member opposite said: "Yes, correct". Even as I say it now-and the cameras do not show it-the member looks at me and with grim determination nods his head yes. All of the witnesses of Canada in this Chamber who can see the hon. member, see him nod his head yes with a grin on his face. He looks like the latest franchise owner of McDonald's hamburgers. He looks like he just had a big mac attack.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
Unfortunately I must interrupt the hon. member and ask him to show me indulgence at this time. I promise I will recognize him later.
It being five o'clock p.m., pursuant to Standing Order 30(6), the House will now proceed to the consideration of Private Members' Business as listed on today's Order Paper.

that Bill S-10, an act to incorporate Green Shield Canada, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Madam Speaker, after the consultations we have had on both sides of the House I would suggest that you would find unanimous consent for the motion that this bill proceed today through consideration at second reading, in Committee of the Whole and at third reading.
I would like to speak very briefly to this bill. It is a very simple matter. It is to straighten the corporate affairs of Green Shield Prepaid Services and to incorporate a new corporation called Green Shield Canada Prepaid Services Association.
The current Green Shield company originated in Windsor, Ontario as a prepaid drug plan service. It has since expanded dramatically throughout Ontario, serving a number of organizations with prepaid drug payment plans and with prepaid legal plans, that class of service. It is a non-profit company.
The company is incorporated provincially in Ontario and it seeks to become a national company. Unfortunately there is no provision either in Ontario law or federal law for it to transfer from one corporation to another corporation, being that it is a non-profit corporation, a not for profit corporation.
The consequence of this bill has been vetted by the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions and of course the Minister of Finance. The bill has had a hearing before the Senate.
It is a very regular type of bill. All it really does is take the company that presently operates in this health care field, selling prepaid services to Ontarians, and moves it to a federal corporation so that it will be able to operate

June 18, 1992

and offer its services on a non-profit basis right across Canada.
Madam Speaker, I think you will find unanimous consent to treat this as a completed bill with three readings, to treat it on that basis.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to consent to the proposal put forward by the hon. member for Mississauga South. I do not know whether he wants to deal with that by motion now, or whether he is prepared that we make our speeches and then at the conclusion of the second reading speeches we could go into Committee of the Whole and deal with the bill at that point.
I am pleased to consent to that, but I would like to address some remarks on second reading of the bill. If that is satisfactory, I will proceed to that now.
The hon. member for Windsor West, who today is celebrating the 30th anniversary of his election, has asked me to substitute for him in dealing with this bill since he is unable to be here this afternoon. He was here earlier, as Your Honour knows. Unfortunately a meeting in his constituency this evening has taken him away from Ottawa for the time being. He asked me to speak on his behalf in respect of this important bill.
Green Shield has carried on business for some time as incorporated under the Business Corporations Act of the province of Ontario. It has been a company with which many members are familiar, at least Ontario members, because the acquisition of health insurance coverage has been common place, particularly as I recall-and I am going from recollection-on items not covered under OHIP or for persons who are travelling.
I understand the business has been a successful one. It is desired to extend the business of the corporation across Canada so that other Canadians in other provinces are able to take advantage of these services. I presume this will lead some additional service being provided or at least competitive services being provided elsewhere.
I am glad to see the Solicitor General has joined us. I expect he will also be speaking in support of this bill too.
As a result the company has determined that the most effective means of achieving the objective is to apply for incorporation by act of Parliament rather than under the Canadian Business Corporations Act. I note that this bill
Private Members' Business
is intended to incorporate the company on that basis, as incorporated directly by act of Parliament. It is a fairly unusual step to be taken today for new companies. Usually private members' bills that come before us amend incorporating acts of corporations that were incorporated many years ago. However in this case apparently Green Shield has decided to proceed in this way, and that is quite satisfactory.
In addition, as I understand it there was some discussion in the other place when this bill was debated as to what happened to the profits of this corporation. My understanding is that there is a foundation of a similar name which has received these profits over the course of the years Green Shield has been in operation and uses the profits for various charitable purposes.
Also my understanding is that the foundation was incorporated under the laws of the province of Ontario. Therefore, in the event of dissolution of the foundation its moneys would be payable to charitable objects only in Ontario. To resolve that problem, I understand that Green Shield has now incorporated a new foundation under the laws of Canada so that, again in the event of dissolution of the foundation, the profits could be distributed to other charitable objects throughout Canada. I understand that has solved a possible problem with this bill that might have met with some objection as it proceeded through the other place.
I note that my colleague, Senator Frith, made an excellent speech in the other place on this bill in the course of the debate there.
Having dealt with these minor problems of incorporation in various jurisdictions, having dealt with the matter of the disposition of the profits through the charitable foundation, I think the about to become a company, Green Shield Canada, has met the possible objections that could have been raised to the procedure it has chosen to adopt. It has come before Parliament.
We recently passed a resolution waiving the normal notice provisions in respect of the petition, its lateness in any event. That has happened with respect to the three bills we may end up dealing with during private members' hour today.
We are now in a position where the bill can proceed through this House, following which it will receive royal assent. If that happens the company will then be incorporated and everything will move along smoothly.

June 18, 1992
Private Members' Business
This procedure is unusual. I think it is the first time an incorporation has been done in this House since I was elected. I am interested that this procedure is still available to corporations or groups of individuals that seek to incorporate in this way. It is an ancient procedure, one that dates back many, many hundreds of years. Certainly many of the early English corporations were established by act of the British Parliament.
The power to carry out this incorporation went on here for some time. There were two principal means. One was the granting of a charter by the Crown such as the Hudson's Bay Company got in our early corporate history. Then as Parliaments got busy passing these private acts incorporating companies, it was decided to proceed with easier techniques by passing things like the Business Corporations Act which allows incorporation without recourse to the legislature. That is the usual way of incorporation in Canada today. This is quite an unusual procedure but nevertheless entirely proper and quite interesting.
For legal students who study corporation law this particular precedent will be an interesting one because of the fact that this corporation clearly carried on business previously in the province of Ontario as a business corporation and through its foundation incorporated in the same province, I am not sure under which act but I expect under the corporations act of Ontario. I suspect there were two different provincial acts involved in the operation of the company.
Having said that, I am pleased to support this bill. I commend the hon. member for Mississauga South for sponsoring it in this House and for his efforts in ensuring all-party support for the bill and the co-operation of members on all sides of the House on its speedy passage.
I hope that will be forthcoming a little later this afternoon.

Madam Speaker, I rise to support Bill S-10 which, as has been cited, is an act to incorporate Green Shield Canada at the federal level. As has been pointed out too, it is a rather unusual process that we deal with in looking at this Senate bill.
Of course, as I said, I support it. I should tell the House something about Green Shield. Green Shield is a
not for profit company that provides among other things prepaid dental, medical and hospital insurance and has a considerable tradition in this country.
I point out with some pride that it originates in Windsor. It in fact administers some 750 plans with 500 participants and processes nearly five million claims.
Groups served by Green Shield range from as small as six to 35,000 including GM, Ford and Chrysler. Its annual revenue exceeded $200 million in 1991. Its 1992 fiscal plan calls for revenue to exceed $230 million. It is, like the city of its location, a socially useful and dynamic company.
This bill permits the transfer of jurisdiction from Ontario to Canada on terms that provide for appropriate regulatory authority by the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions.
An incorporation by a special act of Parliament is the only viable option that Green Shield has so that it may realize the goals of federal incorporation and achieve a national scope within a single regulatory framework. Otherwise the process would be exceedingly and excessively complicated.
There has been a thorough review of the bill at both the policy and the regulatory levels. Green Shield representatives have worked closely with the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions and the Department of Finance to ensure that this legislation would be appropriate.
I would only summarize by saying that it is a bill made necessary by a series of complicated circumstances.
The outcome will not only benefit the company, but I can assure you that having Green Shield converted to Green Shield Canada can only accrue to the benefits of Canada and to those who need the kind of services that Green Shield has so effectively provided in the past.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to support this proposal and second reading of Bill S-10.
As has been explained in the Senate and earlier today in the House, the purpose of this legislation is to allow Green Shield Prepaid Services Association to transfer its jurisdiction from Ontario to Canada. Its new name will be Green Shield Canada Prepaid Services Association.
June 18, 1992

Since Green Shield is a not for profit association, one with no share capital, it is not a simple matter for it to incorporate federally. Under the Canada Business Corporations Act, entities that wish to incorporate must have share capital. Green Shield Prepaid Services Association has no share capital. It has no shares or shareholders.
Similarly, the Ontario Business Corporations Act requires share capital in order to incorporate. In Ontario, Green Shield was incorporated under Part III of the Ontario Corporations Act, and is registered or licensed under the Prepaid Hospital and Medical Services Act.
Because of a defect in the Canada Corporations Act, Green Shield cannot be continued federally. Furthermore, if it did try to incorporate under Part II of the Canada Corporations Act, the statute which deals with the incorporation of not for profit associations without share capital, it could not register or license federally to carry on prepayment plans because there is no federal statute equivalent to the Prepaid Hospital and Medical Services Act.
The remedy, therefore, is incorporation through an act of Parliament and licensing under the provisions of the Insurance Companies Act. This is what is provided for in Bill S-10. I have been assured that this approach has been taken only after extensive consultations with the Ministry of Finance and the Office of the Superintendent of Insurance.
In the Senate it was mentioned that Green Shield introduced the first North American prepayment prescription drug program in the 1950s. Since then, it has extended its coverage from pharmaceuticals to dental, legal and other services, and covers workers in most Canadian provinces.
Though it contracts with employers headquartered in Ontario, the employees who may reside and work outside of Ontario are nevertheless covered by their employer's plan with Green Shield. By incorporating federally, Green Shield will be able to contract with companies that are headquartered outside of Ontario and with individuals who reside outside of Ontario. This is the underlying purpose of Bill S-10.
Tbming to the bill itself, I refer members to clause 4, subclause (1) which reads:
The objects of the Association are to provide, operate and
administer prepayment plans throughout Canada.
Private Members' Business
Prepayment plan as defined earlier in the bill refers to the prepayment of the costs of specified services. The term specified services is itself defined as follows:
such social, health, dental, legal, pharmaceutical or other services as are specified in a prepayment plan
These are the endeavours that Green Shield is interested in pursuing nationally.
Subclause 4(2) of the bill reads:
The Association shall carry out its objects as a non-profit organization and for socially beneficial purposes, without purpose of gain for its members, and any profits or other accretions to the Association shall, subject to section 10, be used in promoting its objects.
We have a non-profit organization which will operate prepayment plans for "socially beneficial purposes". If there are any profits, they will be funneled back into the promotion of its objects, namely, the operation and administration of prepayment plans throughout Canada. If they wish to get into other business activities or operate prepayment plans other than those concerning health, dental, legal or pharmaceutical services, subclauses 7(2) and 7(3)d require the consent of the Minister of Finance.
Clause 8 provides that if the directors wish to wind down the company by transferring its prepayment plans to another entity or by selling all or substantially all of its assets, approval must be obtained from its members and the Minister of Finance. If the association is dissolved or wound up, an obvious question is what happens to the assets. After all, there are no shareholders.
Subclause 10(2) provides that following the payment of all obligations the balance is distributed not to the members of the association, but to "such charitable or non-profit corporations as are designated for that purpose in the by-laws". Where there is no designated recipient, subclause 10(3) provides that the Green Shield Foundation will receive the remaining assets.
This non-profit foundation incorporated under Part III of the corporations act of Ontario in the 1970s is not now active. It was established in order to prevent the reoccurrence of the Windsor Medical Services Inc. incident, where, with the introduction of the Ontario Health Insurance Plan in 1969, Windsor Medical Services was wound up and following lengthy litigation, its surplus distributed to the doctors who were members of the corporation.

Private Members' Business
If Green Shield Canada Prepaid Services Association were to wind up, the surplus would go to a non-profit entity and not to individuals. I also note that clauses 16 and 17 of the bill specify that the Winding-Up Act and the Insurance Companies Act apply to the association. In the case of an involuntary dissolution, both statutes apply. Where there is a voluntary dissolution, only the Insurance Companies Act applies. In either case, the Superintendent of Financial Institutions will play a leading role.
The Superintendent of Financial Institutions also has a role to play if the association wishes from time to time to distribute any surplus it has accumulated. Subclause 10(1) of the BUI S-10 reads:
When the Association has, in the opinion of its directors, unappropriated surplus in excess of the requirements of the Association, it may, with the approval of the Superintendent distribute all or part of the excess to such charitable or non-profit corporations as are designated therefor in the by-laws.
I assume that the charitable or non-profit corporation that would be the logical candidate for the surplus is the Green Shield Foundation. As for the Superintendent of Financial Institutions, his role would be limited to ensuring that the distribution of a surplus would not endanger the continued viability of Green Shield Canada Prepaid Services Association. The Superintendent would not be concerned with where that surplus went, as long as its distribution was not imprudent.
There are of course certain advantages in activating the Green Shield Foundation. As I mentioned earlier, the association is limited as to the types of activities it may pursue. If it wishes to step outside its authorized activities, permission of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions must be obtained.
The Green Shield Foundation, however, apparently has a greater range of permitted activities. Green Shield could launch initiatives through its foundation that it could not pursue through its association.
There is one aspect of this relationship that intrigues me. If Bill S-10 passes, we will have a federally incorporated association that eventually could be operating throughout the country in every province and territory.
It receives payments from individuals and corporations in every region of the country, accumulates a surplus which it then transfers to its foundation under subclause 10(1) of this bill. The foundation then uses this surplus to fund a new scheme. The foundation, however, is incorporated in Ontario, and like the present day association, is limited in its dealings outside the province. The end result is that the foundation launches a new scheme of benefit primarily to individuals and companies resident in Ontario, funded at least in part from the nation-wide operations of the association.
If the foundation as well as the association were incorporated federally, I would not be raising this scenario. In any event, it is difficult to speculate about this without knowing more about the foundation. Perhaps we can pursue that another time.
I suggest that we give this bill second reading and refer it to committee where this issue can be discussed along with other issues. I look forward to hearing from members who are supportive of this and wish it speedy passage.

speechtext: I understand there is unanimous consent for this motion to be brought to a vote at second reading at this time.
Agreed.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Is it the pleasure of the House to adopt the motion?
Agreed.
Motion agreed to, bill read the second time and, by unanimous consent, the House went into committee thereon, Mrs. Champagne in the chair.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
Order. House in Committee of the Whole on Bill S-10, an act to incorporate Green Shield Canada.
Clauses 2 and 3 agreed to.
On clause 4-Objects of Association

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext: Madam Chairman, I wonder if the hon. member for Mississauga South could tell us whether the terms of clause 4 are normal for this kind of corporation in Canada. Has he had any opportunity to review any other acts of incorporation?

Madam Chairman, this is a very standard clause that provides the objects to operate the corporation. I would not think there should be any particular difficulty. The objects speak for themselves.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clauses 5, 6 and 7 agreed to.
On Clause 8-Transfer of Plans, etc.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I wonder if the hon. member for Mississauga South has inquired whether there would be any tax consequences on the transfer of assets under this bill.

Madam Speaker, it is a not to profit corporation so the corporation files are not for profit return as a charity. The consequence is that there are no tax complications that arise as a result of the transfer of the assets of the Ontario corporation and the conversion of the Ontario corporation, as it presently is, to the Green Shield Canada not for profit corporation.
Madam Chairman, could the member tell us whether there is any GST on the transaction?

Madam Speaker, I do not believe there is any GST because it is not selling anything. All it is really doing is transferring a corporation from one jurisdiction to another so that the entity remains the same. It changes its names and its jurisdiction but it remains the same and consequently being no sale, there is no goods and services tax.
Clause 8 agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 16 inclusive agreed to.
On clause 17 -Application of the Insurance Companies Act

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext: Madam Chairman, has the hon. member for Mississauga South checked all these sections of the Insurance Companies Act that may apply to this particular company to make sure that they are all the correct ones?

Yes, Madam Chairman. The provisions I think the member is speaking about are the Winding Up Act, the Bankruptcy Act
Private Members' Business
and the provisions are particularly eliminated with respect to the transfer and the new association created.

Madam Chairman, the hon. member misunderstood my question. It was in regard to clause 17 of the bill. The provisions of the Insurance Companies Act, there are quite a large number of them, are said to apply to this association. I wonder if the hon. member has had a chance to review all those sections of the Insurance Companies Act and could give us his assurance that these are all the ones that ought reasonably to apply.

I have and these indeed are the sections of the insurance act that apply. They are incorporated into this bill because that is the easiest way to put them into this act.
Clause 17 agreed to.
On Clause 18-Amendment to OSFI Act

This clause has to do with the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions. I wonder if the member from Mississauga could inform the House of discussions with the office of the superintendent and if he believes this is a good piece of legislation.

To acquaint the House, Green Shield had a series of meetings with the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions on the organization of this bill. The way the bill is presented was the result of those discussions. This legislation is really the creation of the solicitors for Green Shield, together with the office of the superintendent, working through the Minister of Finance, on the incorporation of this bill to transfer from Ontario jurisdiction to federal jurisdiction in the manner of this bill.
Clause 18 agreed to.
Clauses 19 and 20 agreed to.
Clause 1 agreed to.

Preamble agreed to.
Title agreed to.
Bill reported.

Madam Speaker, I am prepared to give unanimous consent to proceed with the bill through all stages, but I want to tell the hon. member that I would like an explanation of the purposes of the bill in the course of his remarks. He does not need to keep it short.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: There is unanimous consent.

that Bill S-9, an act to amend an act to incorporate the Northwest Canada Conference Evangelical Church, be read the second time and, by unanimous consent, referred to a Committee of the Whole.
He said: Madam Speaker, Bill S-9 is a very short bill. It contains only two clauses.
The purpose of clause 1 is to remove the present limitation on the value of property that may be held by the church.
Subsection 7(2) of chapter 79 of the Statutes of Canada 1928 at present reads as follows: "The aggregate value of the real estate held by or in trust for the corporation in Canada shall not exceed at any one time the sum of $1 million".
This clause would remove the limitation of the church to hold more than $1 million worth of assets. It does not put any new limitations, it simply removes that particular limitation.
Clause 2 would provide the church with a French name. The French name of the corporation incorporated by the said act is Conseil de I'Eglise evangelique pour le Nord-Ouest du Canada. I am sure that will come out a lot better in the translation.
The member opposite suggested a detailed explanation. It is basically to reflect the changes in today's society, the real estate values that may have implicated this as it has many other churches in expanding and developing assets across the country.
The second section of the bill recognizes the cultural diversity of Canada and places it within communities in which the second language may be required for those people who are involved. It would assist the church in meeting today's challenges in continuing to serve the spiritual needs of thousands of Canadians.
June 18, 1992

That is basically what is being asked for, the changes that are requested, and I would respectfully submit that bill today.
