The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Andre that Bill C-73, an act to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope; and the amendment of Mr. Boudria (p. 10744).

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: There were three and one half minutes left in the speech of the hon. member Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte. I will now recognize the hon. member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon.

Madam Speaker, if the hon. member who still has three and a half minutes left is in the back, I would be willing to relinquish the floor and begin my speech later.
I appreciate the opportunity to add to the debate we have had for most of this day with respect to the proposed changes in the Canada Post Corporation and what the changes in section 27 of the Canada Post Corporation Act are trying to accomplish.
I should say at the outset that since I have been in the House of Commons, I have followed the issues concerning Canada Post as a critic. I have been very impressed with the majority of things they have been doing in the last three or four years. Their management and their people have tried to bring the delivery of mail and parcels into the 20th century.
I am particularly impressed with Canada Post when I visit their facilities across the country. Members on my side of the House are glaring at me because I am complimenting Canada Post. I will get their comments after I am finished with mine.
Canada Post has the ability to adapt to the manufacturing processes of the 20th century. They take a parcel or a letter or whatever it may be, which they call a unit of production, and figure out the best way to facilitate it. When you take a look at what Canada Post has been doing with respect to management and employee responsibility in such a tiered process, there is a tremendous responsibility at every level of the operation. Many businesses in this country can learn some very important lessons from the way Canada Post handles its operation today.
June 18, 1992

I also see that in the merchandising and the services it provides. If I recall correctly, at one time it had relinquished the field of delivering parcels and especially letters on time. We find now its merchandising policies and its dedication to providing a service on time is truly a credit not only to those who serve in the management of this Crown corporation, but every person who is responsible for every step of the process for getting a letter or parcel posted in one part of the country and delivered in another in fairly good time. The employees and the management should truly be complimented.
That is why I have some difficulty today trying to understand what Canada Post is attempting to do with the legislation that is before this house. There are many more pieces of legislation that we have to discuss. There is the Immigration Act tomorrow that requires at least 10 days or two weeks of debate and yet we are going to try and cram it into two days and here we are talking about a piece of legislation with respect to changing Canada Post which really makes no absolutely no sense at all.
I will comment in a few moments on why I do not think this legislation should really be here and be discussed and debated in the House today.
Let me say that although Canada Post is truly impressive in a great many areas today, in my judgment it forgot some of the fundamentals of what the Canada Post Corporation truly is.
I come from a mid-sized community, Thunder Bay. I also represent many areas of a rural nature. Nipigon has its own little post office, Red Rock has its own post office, Armstrong has its own post office, Gull Bay is serviced by Armstrong, Dorion just recently closed down its local office and has its facilities handled by good friends of mine, the Atkinson family.
What we find is that in many small rural communities, not only in the area I represent but throughout this country, perhaps the only federal presence we have in that community that is representative or symbolic of Canada is the local post office.
It is the only facility that carries the Canadian flag, that has the Canadian colours, that has the Canadian symbols. This is where Canada Post truly has gone astray.
Government Orders
When Canada Post started closing down these rural post offices under the guise of offering better services-it may be offering better services but I am not prepared to make that admission right now-what it is doing is closing down institutions which have been part of rural Canada for the last 100, 115 or 120 years. What is catastrophic is that with the closure of those rural post offices in those small communities it has removed all vestiges of a federal presence.
I do think that given the history of Canada Post and given its background and the services that it provided to this country, not only to large urban centres but throughout the country into small communities, more than anything else is the knowledge of all Canadians that there is a national presence in those small communities. Canada Post provided more than just the delivery of mail, the reception of mail and the forwarding of mail.
That small rural post office has been almost a social net, where people as they get elderly and have lived in a community for years and have had the opportunity to go down and pick up their mail in the morning, meet and discuss items of mutual interest, the post office has become a meeting point. I agree that that is not the responsibility of Canada Post but it is the responsibility of the Canadian government and a responsibility that we have inherited and we should not do away with.
Canada Post in its rural settings not only provides a national presence but it has the ability to assist those people. We all know today that if you do not have some legal training I doubt whether anyone in this country, even with legal training-I have some legal training-can fill out and complete all the forms that most citizens have to do in order to carry on with their day-to-day living.
The forms they have to fill out for their citizenship, to begin with, the forms that they have to fill out for getting their driver's licence, the forms they have to fill out to get their old age security, their old age pension, and the myriad of problems that arise when we have such a social net within our country, Canada Post in its rural setting and through the very fine people who work in those rural post offices, provided that service, provided that advice, provided that assistance to those small communities.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
I wonder, when these small rural post offices close down, how those people who before had been able to get that type of assistance through their small rural post office, are going to go to get that assistance now.
Having said what I said at the outset about Canada Post, I think their management has gone just a step too far, and has developed perhaps too intense a business concept. It has forgotten the genesis of Canada Post, its beginnings, what it truly provided for a community. I think Canada Post has lost its way.
The other area that I would like to mention, Madam Speaker, in addition to the closure of so many small rural post offices is this new concept where mailboxes are put at the ends of streets in new developments. That may work in a climate where the sun shines and it only rains once in a while, but it does not work here.
I look at my friend from one of our rural ridings in British Columbia. I know my time is getting short, Madam Speaker, but let me just make the point that his constituents are the same as mine. We all grow older and with the seasonal differences in climate and so on, it is just not as good as it once was.
If we were to do anything in this country that would be beneficial to providing better services for all Canadians, it would be to completely remove those ugly post office boxes at the end of every street and to start delivering mail to every home in this country, as it should be.
I oppose this legislation. I do not know why it is here in this House. I do not think anyone knows why it is here in this House. It makes absolutely no sense that 10 per cent of a corporation would be sold to its employees who do not want to buy it. It provides no security for them. It provides no profit. It provides no gain. I do not know what the purpose of the legislation is.

Madam Speaker, it had not been my intention to speak this afternoon on this particular bill or on the amendment. However, the hon. member for Ottawa West motivated me to do so.
When that member was speaking, she said that the socialists were absent from the debate, socialists who believe in socializing everything, and where were they, why were they not taking part in this debate on this particular bill and on the amendment. She effectively
said that we were not taking part in the debate and we were in favour of socializing everything.
She is wrong on both counts. I believe she knows that. I cannot accuse her of telling a falsehood, but I can certainly say that she was exaggerating to say the least.
The socialists of Canada as represented by the CCF and the NDP have never been in favour of socializing everything. However, a service like the post office is a natural candidate for remaining as a government-owned organization. Apart from being a service, it is a monopoly and that is another good reason for it remaining totally under public ownership.
This move by the government to sell off some shares in it is an obvious move to totally privatize it. The socialists who have spoken in this debate-I am not sure how many but two of them today and others on previous occasions-have all opposed the legislation and have supported the amendment to hoist it for six months which of course is killing the bill. We want to do that.
We can all relate our own stories about the post office. I was listening to the member who preceded me and I have some of my own.
I was raised in a relatively small community in British Columbia, South Wellington on Vancouver Island. At that time it had a population of around 500. The post office was a service organization there.
The member talked about various government forms and the assistance that would be given by the postmaster or postmistress in filling them out. Passport applications and old age pension applications, the many forms that one needs in dealing with government which are now picked up by going to a special office in a city could then be picked up at the local post office. Help was available if needed so it was not just forms.
In South Wellington in those days there was one telephone in the community. It was in the post office. Beside the post office was a family-owned grocery store. It was in the same building as the post office but separated by a door that could be locked on occasion. If the telephone rang in the post office and there was a genuine emergency, then it was not beyond members of that family to go and get the person who was required to answer the phone. On other occasions, the phone could be used by people coming into the post office for that purpose.
June 18, 1992

The post office itself, as well as providing forms, was also the nearest thing to a bank that was available to many people. It provided services which are currently available only in banks, a savings organization that was available to the post office. Postal money orders could be purchased in the post office. It really was something that tied Canada together.
If the mail was piling up for one individual, then the postmistress would advise a neighbour. She would perhaps say to the neighbour: "Would you like to deliver this mail to that person?" That is, if it was not registered mail. Or alternatively ask: "Have you seen that person lately? Is he or she well? Is there some problem? Would you like to look in on that person?" With messages like that people looked after each other in those days. The post office was the place that brought them together, the common place where people called, where they met each other and talked. It was a social centre.
It was more than a social centre. It served the people of that community of South Wellington as it did many other communities all across Canada. Today it is not a service organization, it is profit driven. We have lost something in that.
The post office boasts of its success when it makes a profit. In this particular year, I understand it is not making a profit. It is experiencing a loss of some tens of millions of dollars. It mismanaged employer-employee relations to the extent there was a very serious work stoppage, a result of an argument between employers and employees, which cost a lot of money to give something less than proper service to the people.
Whenever there is that kind of stoppage it cannot be blamed on one group or the other. One can certainly say that Canada Post has to take more than its share of the blame for that work stoppage.
It resulted in the loss of service and resulted also in the tens of millions of dollars of losses the corporation will be reporting this year. But that is not so important. It is the service that was lost. Losing money is important, particularly at this period in the history of Canada, but more important is the loss of service.
Government Orders
Loss of service not just because of that work stoppage but loss of service because Canada Post is retreating from its previous policy of taking its service to the people. Instead it is saying: "You come to us. We are not here to serve you. We are here to offer something if you wish, but you have to come to us. Look for us, find us somewhere, and you can then make use of our services."
It is cutting back on the variety of services, the things that used to be available in post offices, making it more difficult for people generally to get whatever service they want from that post office, by having to go further, by having to drive.
In the days I was talking about there was one car in the area of the community in which I lived, one automobile. Now, of course, everyone drives. They go much shorter distances than we had to go to pick up our mail. But in those days we walked to get the mail.
In those days the post office was a service. I do not think it was losing money in those days either, but it offered services far beyond those offered today. It helped to keep Canada together as a nation. It helped maintain contact between people who now find it difficult to maintain contact.
We should be trying to improve that as a service. We should maintain it as a publicly owned organization, an organization that because it is a monopoly and because it is a service, should be a service oriented organization, should be publicly owned and not privatized as this legislation provides.
We have no hesitation. All of the New Democrats when this bill comes up for a vote will be voting in favour of the motion to hoist, recognizing that what we are doing is killing the bill.
We are hoping that we can achieve that and kill it at least until after the election. Hopefully then the new government will turn the clock back and start improving Canada Post, start improving it from the point of view of providing and maintaining a service to people rather than boasting about profits that it makes from not providing an efficient service.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders

Madam Speaker, I join in this debate on Bill C-73, an act to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act, to register my disagreement with the government strategy dealing with Canada Post.
Members on this side of the House have found it very difficult dealing with Canada Post on any grounds. Rather than look at the questions of service and responsiveness to Canadians this government is looking at changes in ownership patterns. It is avoiding the major issue it is supposed to be facing.
I was happy to hear that the previous speaker from the NDP was quick to praise the operations of Canada Post in the old days under the Liberal Party. It is not very often we hear such complimentary comments. We all know that even in those days there were a few problems, but I thank him very much for his support and we hope to be able to return it to the fine levels of service in the next few months and years.
What has struck me, as a member of Parliament, is when looking at which departments are easy to deal with and which departments are totally incompetent, totally unable to respond and totally unable to answer a basic question, on a scale of negatives, Canada Post is front and centre.
Never in all my time as a member of Parliament have I ever been treated so poorly as I have in dealing with Canada Post. The only other organization to treat me so poorly was General Motors but that is another story for another time.
In dealing with Canada Post, I am struck by the fact it is unable to understand that its strategy may be wrong, it may in fact be making a mistake, that it should make changes.
When dealing with the Department of Employment and Immigration for example, the regional director will sit down and talk with a member of Parliament and say: "Well we only have so much money. We think we are going to do it this way. What do you think?" Do you know what? Its officials respond. They talk and they come up with a strategy. It may not always be the one wanted but you know it is the lack of questions dealing with the regional public administration in this House concerning employment and immigration. It is because
of that level that these people seek out members of Parliament and try to develop a consensus.
On the other hand, Canada Post sends what can only be described as God-awful notices at the last minute on a Friday afternoon to indicate that on Monday something is being closed down. Its officials will meet you, under duress, but normally speaking they will not. If they do meet you under duress, it is to explain why things cannot be changed, and they always look so sad.
There was a period two years ago where I had a number of changes in the organization of mail services in Winnipeg North Centre. One of the key points of survival of an older community and older neighbourhood like Winnipeg North Centre is as it goes through a period of decline everyone wants out.
Businesses want out because they are insecure. They have older buildings or the streets are insecure or there is a poor traffic pattern. People living in older homes decide not to fix them up. So it is really up to public institutions to maintain an infrastructure, to make it easy for those who stay there to maintain a life in an older neighbourhood.
Let us take the matter of pulling out the services of mailing parcels, a very simple thing. Older Europeans living in Winnipeg North Centre send parcels back home. All of a sudden, they have to go far away to be able to do it.
Canada Post pulls out a map and says: "This is not far away, Mr. Walker, it is close by. Look at it." I say: "Have you ever got on a bus with those parcels? Do you know that the bus turns that way and the post office is that way? Do you know that you have to walk across seven lanes of Main Street, the worst street in urban Canada and wait for the bus and then get off and walk back across the street?" "Well, Mr. Walker, we have research," they say. I say: "Well that is great, is it market research?" They say: "It is great market research." I say: "Well I spent a couple of years doing market research." They say: "Great, we will get the guy to call you. You will have a great conversation."
It is now 24 months and counting and I am sure one day he will call me and have that meeting. If Canada Post is not willing to sit down and have this basic discussion about the information in which it is changing around communities then why should it be allowed to develop a corporate plan independent of parliamentary scrutiny? The answer is that it should not be allowed to. This
June 18, 1992

government should take responsibility for what it is doing because it is withdrawing basic services.
Back to that famous postal station where these people have to go down Selkirk Avenue, across the street, up on the bus route, and across the street to do their services. Well the post office is now making it more convenient for them. It has closed that post office so they do not have to worry about trying to go there, they can try to find somewhere else.
The frustration that we have is not in dealing with change, because no one in the House of Commons believes that there are not some changes in the service, but in dealing with the quality of the change process. If I phone up public relations in Ottawa and say: "This is what has happened to me in Winnipeg," they reply: "I cannot believe how bad the guys in Winnipeg are. They should not treat you that way, Mr. Walker. We will look right into it." He is right there beside the market researcher and returning phone calls. If phone calls to members of Parliament are not returned, my basic question is to whom do they return them? The answer is that they do not return them to anybody. The frustration with such a basic thing as the postal service is incredible when it should not be that way because you have to manage change.
A few minutes ago the member from Thunder Bay was up talking about what was going on in Red Rock and Nipigon and communities in his constituency. Three years ago, he and I were involved with a non-partisan tour reviewing the cutbacks of VIA Rail. We invited, in good faith, the Solicitor General who was the Minister of Transport. He was offered the opportunity, but VIA Rail was so busy that there was no seat available for the minister. He could only watch us from CTV and CBC.
We asked what the backbone of federal presence was in a town like Red Rock. There were two things. They were VIA Rail and Canada Post.
The government has taken out VIA Rail and that leaves Canada Post. You just heard the member talk about the quality of service as a result of recent decisions. We could go across the country, community by community, and make suggestions to the government as to how to look at issues as they are. One issue is
Government Orders
ownership by employees when employees through their unions have made it quite clear that they do not want that strategy. It is trying to dump on to the employees, something they do not want. You have to ask what it is doing.
You say to yourself that perhaps there is a certain class of employees that is more interested than others. That is not ever spoken about and perhaps we should talk about that. Perhaps it is the first stage of getting the public used to thinking of Canada Post as shares and shareholders. Perhaps the next step after that is privatization.
If privatization is the issue, then put it on the table fellow members of Parliament. Put it on the table, Mr. Minister. Let us see the privatization strategy of this government. Let us not see this piecemeal strategy from one community to the next. Let us have a strategy for dealing with postal service in this country that makes sense. Let us see if this organization can manage change.
It was very boastful two years ago, but now we hear it is going to lose money.
When is that going to be announced? It will probably be late Friday afternoon when no one is paying attention.
No, Wednesday.

Wednesday? It will be after we have gone home. Oh, that's brilliant. Tuesday? Wednesday? This is it. This is like drawing straws. These guys cannot figure which day is the most convenient for them.
I am sure that at the last possible moment we will hear the bad news. I am sure it will be lost because there has been nothing but bad news from this government. That is perhaps another question.
I stand up to oppose what is a very poor piece of legislation. Our critic has had a detailed explanation of our position. He gave it several says ago. Many members from this side have stood up to make the same arguments. We in this particular party have led the charge for the modernization of Canada Post, but in a responsible way that improves communities.
The government makes light of the fact that changes have to be brought in a responsible fashion. It will pay the price for that.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
Madam Speaker, I call upon the government to withdraw this piece of legislation and start over again with building a more responsible postal service.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise to participate in this debate and urge the House to support the motion that would cause consideration of this bill to be postponed for six months.
This debate on second reading gives us all an opportunity to bring before the House the problems that each of us get from day to day with Canada Post and to look at the administration of Canada Post.
I would first like to focus on the larger issue of Canada Post's labour relations. I practised labour law and they used to talk a lot about labour problems. Most of the time when there are labour problems, the real issue is management problems. Good corporations which have good labour relations have properly dealt with those relations.
Canada Post has, without question, the worst labour relations of any company in Canada over any extended period of time. There can be no doubt that it is the experience of all of us that the source of the problem is the management policy of Canada Post. The Conservatives seem to consistently endorse these policies.
Here is a company which still has over 100,000 grievances outstanding. I have personal experience from arbitrators who have been asked to deal with this. The inability of management in this case to get its act together has been completely beyond their experience. There is no doubt where the responsibility lies for this mountain of grievances that remain unresolved. It is with the management of Canada Post. They are unable to deal with the simplest of grievances. They allow them to build up, issue after issue after issue, so that the employees are effectively deprived of what they are entitled to under the law, which is a reasonable disposition of their grievance. That right has evaporated.
The Canada Labour Code has an essential bargain with the labour movement that falls within its jurisdiction. The bargain is this. If one gives up one's right to strike, except at the end of a contract, then the Parliament of Canada will assure an individual an efficient system of disposition of grievances. There is a system set up in legislation to do that. It is reinforced by the collective agreement.
However, here we have a management which has intentionally gone out to destroy the system by failing to deal with it. If anyone argues about the intention of Canada Post management in this regard, you first have the principle that their intention is judged by the effect of their acts. The effect is clearly to destroy the collective bargaining system and the grievance system. Second, it is clearly consistent with everything else that Canada Post management has done. It also spills over into the way in which they deal with the general public.
Let me say that in addition to the pile of grievances which have created an intense morale problem within Canada Post from coast to coast to coast, we see their other work-if it can be called that-with their employees through the rest of the collective bargaining process.
The employees of Canada Post-and I ask those from across the country who are listening to compare it to their own circumstance-have been three years without a collective agreement. Their management has not had the will or the ability to reach a collective agreement for three years. Only with the intervention of this Parliament was there any wage increase voted and that was after Canada Post broke its word to this Parliament and to its employees during the strike last year.
Canada Post, at that time, agreed on certain terms and conditions about the arbitration under which back-to-work legislation would be voted on. The Canadian Union of Postal Workers kept its side of the bargain and withdrew the picket lines. However, the moment the legislation was adopted and the workers went back to work, Canada Post took its part of the bargain off the table. It left the employees and the arbitrator without the agreement they had had from Canada Post.
We have an arbitrator now working on a collective agreement that is going into its fourth year. We have the grievances, the failure to have a collective agreement and a persistent pattern of management which seems designed to bring the whole post office machinery to a halt.
June 18, 1992

I will conclude with a reference to the other aspects of this "management" that the government wants its employees to buy into.
Each of us in our ridings have different problems, but let me refer to a couple in my riding. First, in Victoria, if you want to complain about the service of Canada Post you end up phoning somebody in Vancouver who has no idea where anything is in Victoria in any event and is usually not well trained to deal with the issue. This is a matter of intense frustration-and that is after you have had to take a long time trying to get through on the phone-to the people of Victoria.
The capacity for the public to make complaints or even ask questions about what is happening in Canada Post has been removed from our community which, after all, is the capital of British Columbia, a city of over 300,000 people. It has further taken the ability to actually confront a human being on a person to person basis. All you get is a disembodied voice on a telephone that does not know the nature of the problem in any event.
However, when you can get through that bureaucracy and you can get someone to respond, you get bafflegab. The best example I have is a problem we had in our constituency with condominium apartments. Canada Post decided it was going to compete with those companies that hand out flyers and it was going to offer a service to the companies that wanted the flyers delivered. It provided its own delivery system and hired workers who were non-union, non-bonded.
Good.

The Solicitor General says good, which tells you something about this government's attitude toward the rights of employees to collective bargaining.
It hired non-union employees to go around and deliver these on the weekend. It turned over the keys to apartment buildings which it had entrusted to the letter carriers, to these young kids who go out without a uniform on a Saturday or a Sunday. They were allowed into the building from dawn until late at night. They had complete access to the post boxes of all those who lived in the building. There are many, many seniors who live in these buildings who are very concerned about security. It
Government Orders
created a great fear within many people about the lack of security this involved.
When we started talking to Canada Post about this, we discovered the heart of corporate mentality. It said the customers want this and that. It dawned on us, a group of seniors from these condominiums and me, listening to this official from Canada Post talk, that the customer to Canada Post is no longer the general public. It is no longer the individual member of this community. It is no longer the Canadian citizen and resident who established Canada Post through Parliament in the first place. It is now the commercial venture that wants to peddle its junk mail on the weekends.
I submit that what we have seen is the privatization of the mentality of Canada Post and this bill represents the first step toward the legal privatization of Canada Post because the bill provides for the establishment of shares which in this first instance will be available to the employees. However, it will merely take a stroke of the pen to extend them to those who wish to buy up our postal service and complete the process of privatization which has already begun.
It is a great tragedy for this country that what was an important public service has been destroyed by this government and its predecessor over a period of time. No longer can we say we have a confident Public Service designed to serve the people of Canada. We have an increasingly private company designed to serve the corporate sector in this country. It is a tragedy and a sad day for Canada that this has happened.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to address this issue, Bill C-73, an act to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act.
I find it a little strange that we are debating a bill called the Canada Post bill. It seems to me that the first principle is that the bill should reflect the reality that is out there. As far as I can recall, we have removed that reality. The name Canada Post, Postes Canada, is now called Mail/Postes. We have removed the name Canada.
Why are we calling this bill the amendment to same when it is no longer a reality?

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
Second, and more sadly I guess, is the implication behind the changes that have taken place to Canada Post. I cannot help but call it Canada Post because that is what it is in my memory bank and that is what it has meant to me as a citizen living in a major city but one who has also lived in the country and been part of that small constituency that appreciates and enjoys and recognizes the importance of a rural post office.
I know that when we go to the country in the summertime the first thing we look forward to is going to visit our local little post office. We walk the several miles. It is actually three and a half miles from our home in La Macaza. You go and chat, you meet all the locals, you catch up on the winter stories, what has gone on with everybody, who is well and who is sick, who has graduated from school, where they have a new job, meeting the new children and so on. It is really the centre of communal life in the small rural communities. One of the unfortunate realities of what has happened to Canada Post is the closing down of much of rural Canada.
Rural Canada is alive and well.

I would suggest that the Solicitor General can make his observations. He is entitled to his point of view. I will respect the difference in his point of view. I hope he has at least the decency to respect and listen to what I have to say.
One of the other things that I would find as I went to Canada Post and to my local post office is that I could pick up forms, I could get information, I could send a money order or a money cheque because there was nothing available, no banking services. It was an important institution in the life of the community.
It seems rather a sad critique on this country and how we are looking to building a sense of Canadian unity, a sense of Canadian identity, when we would first of all remove, certainly in rural Quebec, one of the few places where you would see a Canadian flag in every little town through which one would travel. You would have the sense that you are a part of Canada because of the name Canada Post, Poste Canada.
It also would seem to be that if you move from the country area where it serves that important link, you move back into the city area and think about what
Canada Post did on a national scale. Canada Post was a vital element in the supplementation and the subvention of our communication links through our magazines and our community newspapers and our books. Canada Post provided an important subsidy to the delivery of magazines and books and community newspapers and the little church newspapers that kept everybody in the countryside and in the community district well informed of what was going on at the local level.
The government has seen fit to cut more than half the kinds of money used to support our community newspapers. It is a very sad day if you add up all the factors that are cutting down the identifications that represent Canada and that make us feel there is a sense of nationhood. After all, we are more than just the reception and the delivery of service as a postal service. We are also the centre of much business activity.
That business activity which we subsidize in the way of books and literature and community news had a vital role to play. You come from an area where you had a community newspaper, you wrote articles in your community newspaper and members of your constituency have been deprived in many cases of your wise counsel occasionally, some that I would agree with and some that I would not agree with.
On the other hand, you had subsidized air freight and that has been reduced to the Northwest Territories and northern Quebec. If you have seen the price of a loaf of bread and meat and general food up in the north you would know how important that postal subsidy was.
Another thing came to my attention and it is just of recent date that I have noticed this. I do not know about you but as a young person I used to collect stamps and I used to collect the little identifications where the stamp came from. I remember being excited when it came from Europe and what little town it came from in France or England or Israel.
I used to know where it came from and they knew it came from Montreal and they knew that it was perhaps from one of their other friends in the city of Montreal. No longer. It says Canada and the date. That is all it says. Look at the cancellation stamps on your envelopes and see if you do not feel there is a loss of a sense of identity across this country because of a silly little thing like that.
June 18, 1992

I know this is all in the interest of business and certainly I do not agree that one should stay frozen in time. This is a changing society. It is certainly one in which we have moved to the electronic era, to instant communication of all kinds. The fax machine is a perfect example. I do not know now what we would do without the fax and without the car phone. I know life would not be as easy to get along with and we certainly could not cope with lots of things.
I am not saying we should not move forward but I am saying there may be lots of important business principles that are fundamental and changes are needed in our country. A country is not just a business. It is something we seem to have forgotten and I think that is a sad commentary and maybe it is part and parcel of the reason why we are all so cranky out there. We forgot there is something special about a country that is not bottom line business management.
City names have been removed from the cancellation stamps and now you only have a postal code, so you lose your local and regional identity. If you remove "Canada" from Canada Post and if you remove the flag from the rural and urban towns you have a loss of sense of unity. You have something rather strange going on in this particular bill in which the government feels that it should privatize-I should suggest not privatize, although I think that is what is in its mind as you look down the road. Rather, that it is going to sell 10 per cent of the shares to the workers at Canada Post.
I would like to know what kind of a gift package that really is. Canada Post last year lost something in the order of $100 million. You tell me as an enlightened person, are you going to go out and buy shares in a company that is losing $100 million? I do not know about you but I would not do that and I do not know that many of my friends or family would do that. I do not know why the minister thinks this is the greatest thing since sliced bread, that he is offering the workers of Canada Post who, by the way, have the worst record in the world as workers. I do not know if it is their fault or that of the inside organization or the management but they certainly do not have the best reputation in the world.
This minister tells us that this is a great scheme. He is going to sell of 10 per cent of the shares of Canada Post to its employees. As I said, I did not think it was such a great idea and then I come across the fact that the
Government Orders
Conservative majority on the committee that was studying some of the proposals around what to do with the Canadian post office said in its recommendation number 36 that the Government of Canada should privatize Canada Post once adequate financial performance comparable to the private sector levels has been attained and once the industrial relations climate has been improved.
I do not think we have reached the financial well-being of the country, nor does it seem to me that the total industrial relations have been straightened away so that it would seem that even the opposite side of this House would agree that this would be a good idea.
It is our sense that Canada Post should remain a Crown corporation. It should remain a Crown corporation because it should serve us and serve the individual in our society. That is the whole point of having a postal service for anyone.
I do want to talk about one particular problem in my riding that I hope whatever happens will be addressed. That is the question of the supermailboxes. In my riding, in the new areas and in some of the older areas, the giant green supermailboxes are out there. I do not know if the postal service thought you should have one answer for anywhere across this land but in this city, in Mount Royal riding, in the kinds of streets and the type of people we have with the rough ice and snow that piles up, the cold and the sleet and the rain, and particularly the seasons of the year which are very difficult, the senior citizens in my riding cannot get to those boxes. They have difficulty opening the boxes. I would think that service to every home and every door in the metropolitan areas is an absolute must. I would like to see that extended to all the urban areas.
I can understand where that would be difficult in small towns, although I must say that there was a delivery by car and a lovely postman who used to drive up and drop the mail in your little box. It was a really important part of catching up on the news and gossip.
In the major cities in a northern country like Canada, we cannot afford to allow people to go out in the inclement weather and not be able to pick up their cheques.

It is healthy for them.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
You think it is healthy for them. Well, not all these people are as healthy as you are and may you keep your good health.
Come to a small town and find out.

All I can tell you is that it is not the best way. I object, Mr. Speaker. I would like to finish by saying that I really object to this legislation. It is not in the best interest of Canada. It is not in the best interest of the workers. There are a lot of things we can do to improve it, but this is not the right route. I would like it reconsidered.

Mr. Speaker, as I commence my remarks on Bill C-73, a bill to make changes to the post office act, what could I possibly say about the post office that has not already been said in this House over the last 100 or so years. I venture to suggest that everything that could possibly be said about the economies of scale, the cost of postage, the efficiencies of service, the hirings and firings and the patronage and the locations and closings of post offices around the country has all been said 100 times or more.
This particular bill has been described by our critics as the thin edge of the wedge in a privatization. While it in fact is not a privatization, they view it as a precursor piece of legislation. To say the least, they are very cautious about it.
Canada Post is by all measurements a large corporation in significant transition. It has had to move from the age of the hard copy, the hand-written letter, into the age of electronics. It now has competition in terms of communication from other couriers who handle niche markets from the fax machine and from parcel deliveries. In fact, if you think about it, what has really occurred is that the post office this country set up many years ago to handle the mail was to do its job then working with virtually the only medium that existed at that time for communication. In a sense the post office then had a monopoly on the totality of communication beyond the spoken word and that was the written word put in a letter, stamped and delivered by hand to somebody in another location.
Since we gave the post office that monopoly, copying many other countries around the world, we now communicate in many different ways. The simple radio was a means of communication. We have television and other
electronic devices I made reference to. This means that no longer do we have to rely on the post office as a monopoly conveyer of communications. That has changed the role of the post office. That is why in some quarters the post office is looked upon as a candidate for privatization. It is not a monopoly, it is not an essential service the way it was 100 years ago, therefore, it may be a role that government does not have to play anymore. That has been suggested and our critics are vety cautious about that.
The first thing I want to say about privatization is that our party is not prepared to accept half a privatization, a tentative or a punitive privatization or a little bit or a trial privatization. You cannot have half a privatization. Therefore, we are not prepared to support this initiative because it looks good.
I recall earlier in the day when someone asked the same question: Is this a privatization? There was one member opposite who was nodding his head. I know he does not speak for the government, or nod his head for the government, but there is a real sense in this House that the post office is a candidate and this bill is a precursor of that.
Other privatizations this House has looked at and accomplished by legislation over the last few years have made us aware of potential problems, challenges in the process of privatization, and none of that has been addressed as we look at the post office. It is totally premature to look upon this as a possible entry point to privatization.
One of those problems, of course, in privatizing is to get a handle on the value of the assets. In this case I recall in the early 1980s the process by which all of the lands which were used by post offices and owned by Public Works on behalf of Canada and its taxpayers were simply transferred to Canada Post. Millions and millions of dollars worth of real estate in large cities, small towns, villages all over the place was simply transferred to Canada Post without reference to its asset value. We have not begun to assess that asset value in Canada Post.
We on this side of the House are not in the business of giving blank cheques to the government. That is conceptually why we do not want to support this legislation here today.
June 18, 1992

I noted earlier today what for me was a very sad event.
I am not so sure all members had noted it, but we gave third reading to a bill, Bill C-55, governing pensions here earlier today. Within that bill there were two clauses whereby this House gave the Governor in Council the right to make regulations which would override the provisions of the very statute we were passing. That is the first time I am aware this happened in this House.
Some members spoke to it last night but the government did not want to listen. That was called a Henry VIII clause. It is a reference to the last time in history when this really happened in a big way. It was when Henry VIII back in the 1500s decided he wanted that power over Parliament. He wanted the right to override by proclamation provisions of statutes that were passed by the House of Commons, by the Parliament in England.
He got that power, he forced it on Parliament, and the only time Parliament was able to get rid of that was when Henry VIII died, and they did get rid of it. I just want to point out that we in this House gave a blank cheque today to the Governor in Council to make regulations to override what was in our statute.
That was the most ridiculous thing.

That is not just a blank cheque, that is an abdication of our parliamentary responsibilities. If there ever was a thin edge of the wedge that is it. I am cautioning Parliament in that regard.
This bill is purporting to offer a form of employee participation in the profits of Canada Post. There was a time when Canada Post did not look for profits but in this case the corporation has modernized itself and it is pursuing improving economies, better management, more efficiency, and lo and behold, profit.
It has managed to derive a profit based in part I might add by the fact that it is not in a position where it has to write off or depreciate all of these assets of real estate and buildings that were given to it by the taxpayer about 10 years ago. That is water under the bridge. It is potentially a very healthy corporation and there is no reason in the world why it cannot break even and make a profit.
In any event the goal as I understand it from this legislation is to permit employees of Canada Post to
Government Orders
participate in those profits, a form of profit-sharing by letting them acquire by purchase-although it does not say purchase-maybe the shares will be given as gifts, we do not know, with a limit of 10 per cent on the number of shares. They would be non-voting shares and they would be sold, given, transferred or rewarded to employees. In principle, one does not see much wrong with that unless you stop and look at the fact that we have a Crown corporation. I am not comfortable mucking around with the capital structure of a Crown corporation until we in this House have decided what we are going to do with the Crown corporation.
If this House had decided that it was going to be split seven ways or privatized or restructured in any way, then we could talk about all of these other things and business principles.
Right now I think the government is just trying to slide in a little bell and whistle here that is premature because this House has not decided what it wants to do with Canada Post. I know the government has not. If it has, it had better come clean and tell us and not try to slide the thing through with a bill like this.
Let me wrap up and indicate non-support of the bill. I caution about embarking on a quasi-pseudo privatization without fully endorsing the concept and thinking it through and valuing the assets. I caution also about the kind of clause that was contained in the bill earlier today.

Mr. Speaker, I want to continue this debate, focusing on one of the points that my colleague from the town of Mount Royal made about federal presence.
Before I get into the point of federal presence, I want to say up front that I am a fan of the post office of Canada. I know that the post office is probably one of the most efficient companies in Canada.
I remember back in 1981 when we were having difficulties with the post office. There was a major strike on at that time. The efficiency experts went into the post office. They were the types of people who used the same sort of measurement and standards they used in all corporations across Canada. When the study was finished, they discovered that the post office was one of the most efficient companies in all of Canada. It was running at about 97 per cent or 98 per cent efficiency.
When we got these numbers we were absolutely flabbergasted at how the post office could be this efficient and why so many people were upset with the post office. We focused on the area of metropolitan Toronto, which had a very high level of productivity and efficiency. This was even before it was in this mode of privatization.
The problem is that when 20 million pieces of mail are handled in a day, if 2 per cent of that mail does not get delivered within a cycle, which I think at that time was about 48 or 72 hours, then all of a sudden people start complaining; oh, I didn't get my mail on time, et cetera. But 2 per cent or 400,000 pieces out of 20 million pieces is really, by industry standards, not that bad.
As Canadians we do not really appreciate the post office as much as we should. But I take the government to task on this issue of dismantling the post office. When the member from Saskatchewan was talking earlier today, he talked about the fact that in his province close to 100 rural post offices had been closed down. In the country within the last seven years over 1,000 post offices had been closed. When the member for Halton-Peel
said earlier today that he did not want to spend taxpayers' money subsidizing post offices, that is not the way to look at it.
We should realize that these post offices are instruments for pulling the country together, that they are a federal presence. Do not just think of the post office as delivering mail, think of what other supplemental services can be added to the post office so that the federal presence in the community can be enhanced. If there is one thing that we need in this country today it is national instruments that will pull us together. We need the federal presence in this country more than we have ever needed it before.
We know, for example, in some provinces in this country that they do not even fly the Canadian flag. One thing for sure about the post office; you could always count on the Canada word mark, that is the word Canada with the little flag over the a. Remember when that first space arm was opened up in outer space and that Canada word mark was on the side of that Spar Aerospace arm? That Canada with the flag over it gave everybody in this country a great sense of pride, a great sense of appreciation for the talent and the technology of Canadians. It was a patriotic feeling.
The post offices in this country, especially in rural areas, provide that same kind of feeling. They are not just delivery systems, they are symbols of the Government of Canada.
I was approached in my riding office about three weeks ago by a group called the Falcon Group of Canada. In fact, one of their offices is based here in Ottawa. These people have developed a very special technology and they have sold this technology to the United States postal system. It is called the "Postal Buddy Corporation". This postal system, which is like a computerized technology, allows postal patrons to file changes of address, notification for publications of their new address, it prints postage-paid change of address cards, it will organize information on travel trips across Canada. It is very exclusive technology and was developed here in Canada. Interestingly enough, it has been sold to the U.S. postal service before it has been sold to ours. I find that interesting. Mind you, I think that the postal service is going to be seeing them in the next week or so.
June 18, 1992

Here is an example of a Canadian technology, designed and made in this country, which allows the post office to be more than a place where you buy your stamps and get your money orders. It allows the postal service to have new opportunities for generating more revenue and to make it more profitable. That is where the post office should be heading.
If the revenue was there to make it a self-sustaining unit, especially in the rural areas, then surely to goodness the government would not be so preoccupied with closing all of these places which are instruments of national unity.
This debate tonight, where we are focusing on this 10 per cent employee equity participation bill, really should not be a front burner item right now. We should be using the post office to pull us together, to put the federal presence right across this country, especially when it is so inexpensive to set up and operate a post office.
When we get in this bill to where we are talking about this share distribution for employees, I say to myself that first of all there is absolutely no share rights in this share distribution. There is no definition as to how we are going to put a value on this. Just think of the massive amounts of land that the post office owns from coast to coast. How is that going to be factored into the value of the company? Quite frankly, I have never seen a real evaluation for the postal service in this country. I have never seen an evaluation for the land of the post office. How can we going to put a value on these shares?
We know the mistake that was made when we did the share offering on Air Canada. We put it out at almost $2.50 less than what the analysts said it was worth.
What is it trading for now?

The member for Ontario asks what is it trading for now. That is another reason why we should not be in such haste to put out equity in the post office at this moment because the value of those shares is very low, especially property values.
We made the right decision with Air Canada.

Well, you did not really make the right decision in the long-term and I will tell you why you did not make the right decision. The Government of Canada
Government Orders
has now lost its ability to use Air Canada as an instrument of public policy.
That is the one major difference I have with many members on the government side. I really believe that there are times when these instruments like VIA Rail, Air Canada and the post office are instruments of public policy-making and the most important thing that we could be using them for today is pulling the country together.
Look at some of the tremendous difficulties that we are having, not every one but a lot of us, with the Voyageur Program, which is a fabulous program. I salute the Secretary of State for that program, but if we do not follow the programming of Air Canada then there are a lot of youth in this country who are going to miss the boat on the Voyageur Program.
Getting back to the post office, I have always been a big fan of the post office. I am not against equity participation, but at this moment in time when we have so little real definition to give for the value of these shares I just do not think it is a priority issue and it should be put on the back burner.
Let us go back to using the post office of Canada as an instrument to pull this country together. Let us also start looking at some of the alternative ideas out there for rural post offices so that they can provide more sophisticated services like the ones that this Falcon group provides.

Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to speak to the House today about Bill C-73 which will enable Canada Post Corporation to create an employee share ownership plan to allow employees to invest in their company.
Canada Post has changed to better serve Canadians and to meet the challenges of the globally competitive world evolving around us. The participation of employees through the share plan is a common sense next step to ensure that improvement continues.
Over the last 10 years this corporation has learned a lot about corporate reshaping. Its management took the government department it inherited, stripped it down to the basics and rebuilt it. That modem post office began in 1981 when Parliament took some 63,000 employees, fully one-quarter of the Canadian Public Service and said: "Okay, you are a business. Act like a commercial corporation".

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
Back in 1981 the mail had become increasingly irregular. Strikes denied Canadians their postal service for weeks at a time. Annual deficits reached $600 million at that time and to try and equate that, it worked out that probably 5 cents on every letter that was mailed was a subsidy that the taxpayers paid.
The plants of Canada Post 10 years ago were inefficient. They were outdated and contained obsolete equipment. Previous governments had always found more pressing needs for their limited resources than investing in the capital assets for the post office.
This new Crown corporation had annual revenues of more than $1.5 billion but it had no accounting system. It operated from one end of the country to the other but no one knew where the money was going at any given time.
In order to meet the enormous task that lay ahead Canada Post had to begin thinking like a business. By asking Canada Post to prepare and submit annually for approval a five-year corporate plan the government recognized and encouraged this needed change in attitude. As a result Canada Post began to emphasize a corporate culture stressing such values as customer sensitivity, quality, and reliability.
These values are not easily instilled but the corporation has worked over the years to ensure that these will be the values which their employees live day to day.
It is no exaggeration to say that changes the corporation had undergone are staggering. They stood eveiy-thing on its head, examined every process, questioned every assumption. They had to challenge their people every day. They demanded their creativity and their complete commitment. In other words they said to the employees: "Don't leave your brains hanging on the outside door".
The process was a tough one on every one from the executive offices to the plant floors. Some left but many soldiered on and this is a tribute to the quality of these people who have indeed done a fine job.
The purpose of this legislation is to permit these employees who have contributed so much to acquire a piece of Canada Post and enhance their success. Clear evidence that their efforts were beginning to bear fruit appeared in 1988-1989 when the corporation turned a
profit for the first time. This point bears repeating as taxpayers are no longer forced to pay for their postal service twice, once when they pay their taxes, and again when they buy their stamps.
Canada Post has made progress over the last 10 years but it can feel its competitors breathing down its neck every day, not just in Canada, but from around the world.
The sales force is slugging it out with the courier and parcel business and the advertising delivery companies such as newspapers.
Even the basic letter mail is under threat from facsimile machines and new technology such as electronic data transfer. If you have paid your bills lately through an automated teller bank machine then you know what I am talking about.
The corporation's development of new technology and new markets means employees will be fundamental to building on that achievement as the corporation expands its courier, postal, and mail information transfer business. Employee participation as proposed in this legislation will contribute to a new sense of partnership between management and employees. The whole point of the plan is to form a partnership whereby employees feel more on the inside than on the outside in order to meet the competitive challenges that business faces.
I am pleased that it has discovered a growing market out there for its systems that can be put into place to get its operation under control. I am talking about these new technologies that have been developed through Canada Post. Indeed it is already close to a multimillion deal with the New Zealand postal service and is implementing control systems there.
Canada Post's international reputation is such that it was recently recommended by the World Bank to Venezuela which approached the bank seeking assistance in upgrading its postal system. This sort of recognition by a major multilateral organization like the World Bank sends a clear message of the high regard in which Canada Post is held internationally.
The opposition would have the government return Canada Post to the days of the pony express. I would urge members opposite to take a close look at the new Canada Post.
June 18, 1992

What we have here is a made-in-Canada success story. Canada Post has won international acclaim and respect for what it has achieved over the last decade. The new Canada Post is providing Canadians with postal service for the 21st century. The members opposite should accept once and for all what all Canadians and Canada Post know, that Canada Post has become a world leader in its field. The government knows that and that is why I will be supporting Bill C-73.

Mr. Speaker, I want to just follow up. I am actually a great believer in employee involvement in the ownership and management of companies because I think it furthers the idea of partnership in making progress. There is also the concept that employees-not just management and not just executives-create the success of any corporation and any endeavour.
However, I do not think that is what this bill is all about. If this is what Canada Post wanted to accomplish with this bill, it would have worked with its employees to see what kind of greater partnership they would be interested in in running the mail service in this country. It would have been a mutual deal. It is not. That is the reason you have had the comments from this side of the House, Mr. Speaker. It is quite clear that the government is following a matter of political ideology and launching the way to privatization of postal service in this country, just as it has with a number of other areas of public enterprise that still serve major public policy purposes.
I want to talk about CN Express, for instance. Again, the government went through a two-stage process of hiving off the trucking operation of Canadian National. A short time later it privatized it. With Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, it hived off and separated the two operations of Nordion and Theratronics. A short time later, it privatized them.
We know perfectly well that the public never finds out in these privatizations the worth of the property that was invested in and nurtured over many decades. They do not know what it was sold for and what special deals were made behind closed doors to the benefit of the purchasers.
Let me give just one example of CN Express, which became CN Route Canada and then Transport Route Canada and then went bankrupt. That deal included $60 million worth of real estate bought and paid for by the
Government Orders
taxpayers of Canada. It was transferred to private ownership and then bled off to other companies before the company went bankrupt. It left hundreds of employees across this country without jobs and in jeopardy for their pension plans and other benefits that they were entitled to.
The same problems have occurred in other privatizations. We have to remember that this is not something that just appeared out of thin air, whether it is Canada Post or CN Express or Air Canada. This is something that Canadians have invested in because they believe it is something that is good for Canada.
The two most essential public services that Canadians have invested in are communications and transportation. We put a lot of money into those public services because we believed that there is a cost to being Canadian. We pay that cost so that people in the far reaches and in the smallest communities of this country can be part of the community of Canada.
However, it has cost us money. When you have invested in a property, you expect to know that you are getting value for it when you sell it. That information is never available to Canadians. There is never an evaluation, as my friend for Broadview-Greenwood has said, of what we have invested, what it is now worth, what the purchaser is getting and what the taxpayer should get back in the public coffers as the price of that product.
The employees are getting nothing. It is a shell game. They get shares that they cannot vote on and do not know the value of. They do not know whether there will ever be any dividends on or any profit on these shares. Come on. Make me an offer that I cannot refuse. This is not it.
I do think that we are headed down the road of privatization, so I want to talk about some of the ways in which Canada Post has achieved what the member for Cambridge called efficiencies and profit. For one thing, it has jacked up the price of a postage stamp and virtually every service that it provides. It simply transferred the burden on taxpayers from general revenues to the price they pay for the service.
There is no cost saving. It is the same cost. It just means that those who are dependent on mail service to communicate with the rest of Canada are paying more and we collectively are paying less for a service that we think is important to national unity.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
I referred earlier, when I spoke today, to the large numbers of seniors in my riding who have seen their access to postal services gradually shrink. These are the kinds of things we have to look at as a nation knowing that we are going to have an increasingly older population. How do public services adjust to allow older citizens to continue to be fully involved in their community?
Taking away services and asking them to go a mile to a post office or a mile to pick up a registered letter instead of across the street is not progress for society. It is a diminution of services. It is a reduction in the quality of life for Canadians. Yet I can tell you from numerous experiences in my own riding that Canada Post does not pay attention to these issues. This is because, as the member for Cambridge has said, its main drive is to save money to make profits and not to provide service.
With its ideology that the private sector can do it better, it makes absolutely stupid decisions like duplicating services within 100 metres of each other. Where there is a perfectly good postal station that is capable of delivering full services, Canada Post has to say: "Oh, no. That is not good enough. We need to privatize part of that service".
So 100 metres away it opens up a private sector outlet. Now, instead of the convenience of going to one location to buy stamps, weigh a package and pick up registered mail, you go to one location to do some of those things and then you go to another location to do others. In the meantime, you have spent 10 minutes pulling out into traffic and parking again to accomplish what you used to accomplish in two minutes in one location. That is why I say that what we are talking about here is a pattern of ideology and not better service and not less cost.
We have a post office that is saving money at a time when our trucking industry is in trouble in Canada. We also have a post office that says: "We will go where the best bucks are and if that means transporting the bulk of our mail by American truckers then we will use American truckers". Forget completely that the Canadian trucking industry is bleeding to death.
Does that make any sense in the public interest of this country for a public corporation to be seeking only the
best price and not the public good? Of course it does not make any sense.
Anybody can make money by cutting services, by sticking up community post boxes and by doing crazy little things like having a group of homes in the middle a built-up area where everybody else gets door-to-door mail delivery and a handful of homes do not. Is that what we believe in in this country?
I always thought that we believe that wherever you live in Canada you are entitled to be treated equally by your public institutions or at least fairly. Is it fair that I get door-to-door mail service five days a week and my neighbour, not five minutes away, has to bundle up her two little kids in the cold and truck off down the street to get her mail? Of course that is not fair and that is not Canadian.
Anybody can make money if they are willing to mistreat people, to cut out jobs, to abuse people and to have them working in abusive working conditions.
The Solicitor General is sitting over there acting as if none of this is important and none of this matters.
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Since this is for the record, was that 600 feet? I just want to make sure for the record that this long trek with the kids was 600 feet.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I would like to say to the hon. member for Ottawa West that her time now has expired. I will let her finish in 30 seconds.

Simply in order to respond, it is obvious that the Solicitor General has never bundled two kids in the middle of winter and trekked them anywhere. I made no reference to any number of feet.
I resent the interruption and the lack of concern of the Solicitor General for the diminution and the degradation of service to Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I want to raise a number of questions and attempt to address them with respect to the government's attempt to amend this particular act.
The first question I want to ask is how will it improve mail service for Canadians? No one has addressed that. There is an assumption that if this were going to happen then that would follow. I am not sure that is true.
June 18, 1992

Before I get into that and give you specifics as to what has happened in my own constituency, I want to talk about the efficiency factor. Everyone knows that we are spending roughly $155 billion, we are collecting $125 billion in revenue and there is approximately a $30 billion shortfall. We have to be sensitive to losing money in whatever sector. However, when we talk of efficiency, we have to talk about it in terms of the impact it has on citizens.
We know that as a result of some of the changes that have occurred recently in Canada Post the last few months and years, there are in fact fewer services available to Canadians. We know that in some instance the quality has improved, but there are instances where the quality has not improved. If we want to be fair we have to acknowledge that.
We know as well that the prices have gone up rather dramatically. I am not even talking about the goods and services tax that has been added to stamps and a number of other products.
Efficiency is important but at what cost?
The basic premise here is Canada Post is supposed to provide a service to all Canadians in a fair, equitable, sensitive kind of way. This is what has happened in my constituency. I want to give a few examples.
There have been many changes to postal outlets. There have been some closures, but in many instances it is really the amount of service. The number of services available has changed.
For example, in 1989 Marion Pharmacy was changed. A full postal outlet in this area closed despite numerous letters and petitions and Canada Post was supposed to offer certain services but never followed up.
Metro Drugs on Autumnwood Drive closed in the fall of 1990. There are other examples as well. McCullogh Drugs (Tache and Marion) closed within the last two years, as did the Drake pharmacy outlet in 1991, despite all the comments that were made by senior citizens from the area.
In all of these areas the people who have been most affected are seniors, people with disabilities, particularly if they happen to be physical disabilities. I think we have to recognize that.
I want to tell you about another recent change. Roughly a month ago I was at a meeting in St. Germain
Government Orders
which is in the southern part of my riding, a small little community. Canada Post was there. It was a really fine meeting. It was explaining to the citizens exactly what was going to change.
It would appear at first glance that it is going to replace what the citizens had with something that is perhaps roughly of the same quality and I hope so because I want Canada Post to know we are watching very carefully.
How will this particular bill improve the service of millions of rural Canadians whose post offices have been closed? It will not. How will this particular bill improve, for example, the supermailboxes?
We know that they freeze up, you cannot get them open, and we know people are inconvenienced because they are not always easily accessible. How will it improve these kinds of services? There is no way it will improve them. I am told as well there has not been a significant amount of consultation with respect to these changes.
I want to tell you a little anecdote. A woman called my office. She had addressed correctly in a package a watch she was sending to Calgary with her return address. Lo and behold that company had closed. Lo and behold the watch never came back. It cannot be found and Canada Post will not make up the loss.
When I ask the question of how will the service be improved, no one has bothered answering me and I am not at all convinced, if I look at the record of Canada Post over the last few years, that the service will be improved.

On the contrary, I believe that it will continue to deteriorate and I am very sad about that because, as I just said, most Canadians in my riding and elsewhere in Canada will be affected, and especially seniors, people whose mobility is reduced, who find it difficult to go from place to place. I do not like that.

The other major question I wanted to ask is how will this help employees? Many of you will know there are a number of employees of Canada Post who have not had a contract for a number of months. It is more accurate to say in a number of years. They have been through the various steps of conciliation, arbitration, who knows what else, and still nothing has been done.

Government Orders
For example, I had a postal worker, a delivery person, who asked me a couple of months ago what is happening. Why is nothing being done? How will this improve the plight of the worker? I cannot see it.
When we look at the offer that has been made we are talking about 10 per cent of the shares but they are non-voting shares so the employees cannot be part of the decision making. They cannot be part of the board. What is it you are really getting?
Of course this is the first step toward privatization. Let us not kid ourselves.
I am one of the people who believes that under certain circumstances and certain conditions it can be extremely helpful.
I was visiting with 400 plus employees of Air Canada at the front today. I asked how many jobs had been lost since they have been privatized. I asked whether they expect more jobs to be lost. They do. Lo and behold, they are very suspicious. I suspect they are even more suspicious than politicians on the opposition side. They believe that there are going to be announcements just a few days after the House rises. It will be very interesting to see whether this prediction comes true. I hope not. I really and sincerely hope not.
Ask Air Canada, which is now privatized, how successful it has been in trying to find a level playing field. Ask how successful it has been in persuading the government that it should have access to the Japanese transportation lines. Ask and you will be told it has had no success at all; none whatsoever.
I would not be surprised that once the Canadian Airlines deal is completed with one the American airlines, it may give Air Canada access to the Japanese market in order to tell it to be quiet. We will see whether that prediction comes true.
I hear the hon. minister making all kinds of comments. I hope they are recorded in Hansard so we can follow them up later on.
Finally, I ask all members what happened to Route Canada. Do you remember that? It was going to be excellent for everyone. It persuaded long-term employees to leave CN to join this new corporation. What
happened to those long-term employees? To make a long story short, my colleague referred to it, it went bankrupt and lost virtually everything. Some of you will know that it is in the courts today. Some people never got paid all of their wages, I am told. Some people have lost their pensions. Some people have lost pensionable years because they could not continue to work. Many of these people were not able to find jobs subsequent to that. In other words, the workers got shafted royally.
Anyone who thinks that privatization is the panacea, I think we have to look at both sides. In some cases it works because the conditions are appropriate, the commitment is there, there is some protection for the workers, some long-term planning, some adjustment programs for those who have to leave.
