However, in many instances it has been a dismal failure. We still have to see how it is going to work out with Air Canada. Certainly we have a lot of proof when we talk about Route Canada.

I also asked a second question: What does this bill provide for the workers? Many of them have been without a contract for three years, I believe. They went through several stages in the hope of reaching an agreement, but nothing, absolutely nothing, has come of it. They become frustrated and offended, and who wouldn't? Anyone who is without a contract for three years, after going through all those stages in the hope of coming to a solution, would be frustrated by less than that.
I do not believe that the employees will be well served by this bill, especially in view of the agreement allowing the sale of 10 per cent of the shares, since, as I just mentioned, they have no say in the corporation's future.
I see that my time has now expired.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to say a few words in connection with this piece of legislation. It appears that from the opposition side we are talking about just about everything other than the piece of legislation. It is saying that Canada Post should keep every post office open everywhere and at the same time it is running Canada Post down.

I would like to speak from the side I came from of being raised in the country. I noticed my friend from Prince Edward Island mentioned the farmer who liked the idea of going 600 feet. We have been doing that all our lives to find that the mailboxes are frozen shut. The farmers have had to deal with that all their lives. They take the children out bundled up or bundle up themselves to go out and get the mail. There are a great number of people who have never experienced this business of having the mail dropped off at their door while they sit inside.
I am not a total advocate of Canada Post. I have had my concerns about its operation.
It is almost like a bank. Everybody loves to hate it, it seems.
In deference to it, certainly it is getting better at the business of attempting to make itself more productive and efficient and I would like to give it some credit for that. We are moving to have an independent or free enterprise retail space, initially in my area, but not the kind of co-ordinated phase-in that we probably should have had. In my riding it has gone from a small post office in a very small municipal gathering to retail free enterprise and is working out very well with more service hours, longer hours and more service hours on the weekends and so on. It has worked reasonably well.
I want to say that initially when it did it, it certainly was not handled in the best manner. It is getting on to it now. It is getting better organized and knows how to handle the phase-in so that the service is franchised into many outlets with longer hours, into shopping centres and this sort of thing and people appear to like that. We have to go with change. It is certainly not necessarily right that everybody trucks to the post office for their mail. The bill does not have too much connection with it.
The legislation is to allow for a stock purchase. People who work for organizations get a lot from that. That will have them develop more interest in their organization as Canada Post employees. That is an important aspect of this legislation.
I want to take a few minutes to say that as a person who has not always lauded Canada Post for its operation, and I still at times feel it could operate much better, it is
Government Orders
certainly improving to a great extent. The delivery time is up to a very respectable level these days.
Also, as we are making the changes to a more private enterprise, that is retail wise, that sort of phase-in is being done in a planned way. It has been done in a way in which it communicates with me as a member of Parliament. We know what it is planning on doing. When that happens it is also communicating with the community. It is communicating with the business community, with its workers, those who use Canada Post, the clients. It is certainly doing a much better job.
I wanted to take a minute in the midst of all this condemnation of Canada Post to stand up and thank it for its drastic improvements in the delivery of mail and also for its improved productivity and efficiency as it moves into 2000 in mail delivery.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak again on Bill C-73. Because the post office is so important to rural Prince Edward Island and so important in the federal district of Cardigan, I take this opportunity.
We have all heard the government's song and dance that the bill is going to improve service for Canadians. After almost eight years we know what the Tories mean when they talk about improving services. The government is closing post offices in rural Canada. That is hardly improving services. It is eliminating Saturday rural mail in Prince Edward Island. Improving service? I doubt it. It is removing the identity of the province. Improving service? I doubt it.
As my hon. friend from across the way indicated, the government did this everywhere else in 1982, but Canada Post realized how important this was for rural Prince Edward Island. It was financially profitable for Canada Post to continue delivering mail on Saturday but, for no reason at all, the government has now decided to eliminate it. This has caused a lot of problems for the older people in particular who live out in the country. There is certainly no way that they will ever get a newspaper on Saturday. This is just some of the unfairness of this government. If this was a financial move that would save dollars for Canada Post there would be some sense to it, but it has lost dollars doing it.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
Along with this is delay in unemployment insurance cheques. Is that what we call improving service? To the vast majority of my constituents the answers to these questions would be no.
The government is trying to. pass the bill off as the best way to improve postal services across the country. It says the post office employees will be able to buy shares in the company and have a stake in its operations. The Tories are saying that by having union members take a cut of the profits, the productivity of the post office will improve. To be honest, I do not think Canadians believe the government.
If you ask me the only people who will benefit from this plan are the people at the top, people like Donald Lander who makes hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, not counting these great Christmas bonuses the government likes to give to its patronage appointees. It is the managers making over $100,000 a year who will buy the shares in the post office. It will not be the letter carriers who make $3,500 a year. Who is the government trying to fool?
As I said earlier today, this bill is an act to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act. If government was truly honest it would call the bill the sell-out of the post office act. The Tories say that only employees of the post office will be able to buy shares. Most Canadians know a little bit about stocks and they know that a stock is only worth something if you can sell it to somebody else. The unions representing the employees say they do not even want to own the post office. What is the point? The point is that the Conservative government is only creating the foundation for completing the privatization of Canada Post.
Let us look at the situation. Hundreds of rural post offices have been closed over the last few years, reducing services but improving profits. Processing stations have been closed, reducing services and increasing profits. Door-to-door delivery in new subdivisions has been eliminated in favour of the so-called supermailbox, reducing services and increasing profits. Literally thousands of semi-post offices, half drug store half post office, have been opened across the country. All of these things have reduced services to Canadians in the interest of profit.
The government is fattening the young calf for the slaughter. The true objective of the Conservative government is to sell the post office, and this bill is just the
first step. The post office is the latest addition to the obituary of national institutions. Air Canada was privatized a number of years ago. At the time the government said it was to improve services. Today Air Canada is run by a couple of Americans who have destroyed airlines in the U.S. The service is now so good that you cannot get a direct flight from Charlottetown, a provincial capital, to the national capital. That is what we call service.
Petro-Canada is on the list as well. The government privatized that one not so long ago. It said it was to improve services to Canadians and allow for more oil and gas exploration. Today Petro-Canada is floating in a sea of red ink. The company is being forced to close thousands of stations across Canada. On the good side, Petro-Canada has recently opened its first gas station in Vermont. That is improving services for Canadians.
I certainly do not want to sound too harsh but it seems to me that everything the government touches goes wrong. The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation has been suffering from budget cuts for a number of years. The government is so committed to serving Canadians that it forced the CBC to fire 1,700 people, close 11 stations, and cancel one of the most popular programs in Atlantic Canada, Land and Sea. I am sure, Mr. Speaker, if you were to see that program you would understand how informative it is. It is an indication of how unconcerned the government is.
Back in 1985 the Deputy Prime Minister, then Minister of Transport, commissioned a study that said VIA Rail needed to be improved. It needed to improve its services to Canadians. In January 1990 Canadians finally saw the improved service when VIA Rail cut a third of its routes and cancelled "The Atlantic" out of Halifax, not to say what it did on Prince Edward Island. If that is what we call service, it must be Tory service.
The bill has nothing to do with improving services. If the government wanted to improve services, it could have stopped closing rural post offices. The government is only interested in its own business agenda to the detriment of the Canadian people.
I have said before and I will say again in most parts of rural Canada the post office is the only place that we see the Canadian flag flying. In these difficult days of constitutional negotiations and concerns about national unity, rural Canadians need to feel that they belong to this country.
June 18, 1992

If the post office is privatized you will see two levels of service, one for the large urban centre where the post office can make a profit, and a lower service for the people in rural Canada.
People in all parts of this country need to feel that they belong to this country and they certainly do not feel they belong to this country when they pay taxes, see their services removed, see their post offices closed, have their unemployment cheques delayed three or four days-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext: And farmers' cheques.

And fanners' cheques, too. I am a farmer and I am well aware how bad I needed cheques, or how bad the bank needs it through me. I am well aware.
I believe my hon. friends across the way do not understand what it truly feels like to be waiting for an unemployment cheque on Wednesday or Thursday, but just because of a little blip in the service it does not come until Monday. Possibly they needed something and were not able to buy it. Our hon. friends across the way seem to forget that. I deal with that every day. It is so unfortunate that the government seems to forget.
As I mentioned before, it is impossible to understand why a government would discontinue Saturday rural mail everywhere across the country. Is that why it was discontinued in Prince Edward Island? It was making a profit. When it cancelled Saturday mail delivery it meant that it was not circulating the local papers. It lost the contracts. In fact Canada Post lost dollars by eliminating Saturday rural mail. But as the hon. minister indicated, it was that way across the country. Sometimes things have to be done differently.
I urge the government not to sell Canada Post.
Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands -
Canso): Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity for the second time today to speak to the principle of this legislation, which is an act to amend Canada Post Corporation.
This morning I spoke to the amendment by our party to have this legislation considered six months' hence or, preferably, never.
Government Orders
My main arguments this morning had to do with the question of why this government was proceeding to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act in the way it has chosen to when there are so many other concerns across the country, particularly in rural Canada, about the operation of Canada Post.
I would like to speak tonight to some of the problems concerning Canada Post and the direction in which this government would want to move that corporation.
This morning when I addressed this issue, I closed by referring to the communities in my riding that have seen their rural post office closed and their postal services systematically reduced. I was mentioning the case of Judique which was recently notified that its rural post office would close and which last night confronted the minions of Canada Post Corporation that were sent to lay out the community's options and calling this a consultation.
I might have mentioned the case of Petit de Grat, St. Joseph du Moine, Monastery, or Orangedale which lost its post office a year or so ago. The Canada Post building which used to be in Orangedale is a pizza parlour and the local residents get their mail from a green box which is located next to the Kwik Mart store.
One community which did not take the closure of its rural post office lying down was the village of Mabou. Under the leadership of Tom Kent, Pauline MacDonald, Herbert Jeromel, Father Bob Neville and many others, this village rallied to fight Canada Post and make the closure of this post office a national issue.
In the process they managed to shame Canada Post into making a small concession in its rigid rural conversion agenda and to allow this community to set up a community corporation, Mabou Communications Limited, to operate the Canada Post office in Mabou and to sell out of that building a range of ancillary services such as computer services, fax services, stationery supplies and other related services in an attempt to make that building a communications centre serving the village of Mabou and all of the surrounding communities which come to Mabou to do their postal service and also many of the other related services they have need for.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
I might say that under the very able managership of Pauline MacDonald at Mabou Communications Limited, if it is possible to make a go of it, it will be successful. It is not going to be easy because they have not been given very much co-operation by Canada Post in being forward looking and seeing how we could make this rural post office work and working with the communities to that end.
The Mabou post office and what they are doing with the Mabou post office I think is a sign of what what Canada Post Corporation could be doing to enhance and extend, instead of reducing the services, which it provides to the rural part of Canada.
What Mabou is doing could be a real pilot, could be showing the way for the future, if Canada Post and this government are willing to look and see what they are attempting in that veiy proud and very innovative community.
Many on this side of the House have expressed a concern about what will happen if Canada Post is privatized. That is something which the minister in charge of Canada Post and many other members on the opposite side of this House have acknowledged is not only desirable but in fact is really the ultimate aim of this government.
Indeed, we are seeing evidence of this in practice with the decision that is before us in this bill which begins the road toward privatization. It makes it easier to accomplish. We are also seeing it with some of the service reductions which are taking place in the rural communities, for example, the end of subsidies to weekly community newspapers. The Oran, for example, out of Inverness in my constituency sells its papers across western Cape Breton, and has many subscribers all across Canada, indeed all across North America. But given the distances involved, it cannot really operate unless it has some assistance with the mail distribution costs.
Canada Post, in ending the subsidies to these community newspapers like The Oran, The Casket, and others in my riding and in other ridings in rural Canada, makes it harder for these newspapers to do their worthy job of communicating to the communities that they serve.
Another example is the dramatic increases in the costs of rental for post office boxes. The people who live just outside the fringe of communities that have still their rural post offices, have to rent boxes. It is another
example of a reduction in service or an increase in price and a movement toward this cost recovery philosophy of Canada Post, and very likely making Canada Post ready for privatization.
Another example, of course, is the centralized sorting which we are beginning to see increasingly with Canada Post. If a resident is mailing a letter in Antigonish to St. Andrews or Lower South River, which is five or six miles away, very soon that letter will take the long trip to Halifax before coming back to the community where it could almost be delivered faster by hand. That is supposed to be improved service.
What these trends mean and show us is the inevitable logic of privatization, what will happen if privatization of Canada Post occurs in the kind of country that we live in. What will it mean? It will mean essentially that we will move to two classes of mail service; one service for urban, densely populated Canada, and the other a lower level of service for the rural, less populated parts of this country. What we will see will be higher prices for all categories of Canada Post service, or a much reduced service.
I realize I have very little time left so I want to close with a suggestion for Canada Post and for this government. They have taken a road that the only way for Canada Post to make a profit is to streamline, rationalize, cut costs. That has meant all of those activities and all of those decisions which I have described earlier. But that is one way of ensuring the profitability of Canada Post. If it withdraws itself to the urban core of Canada and eliminates all the unprofitable parts of the country, then it will probably be able to make a profit because of the higher cost of servicing the rural parts of the country.
Has this government ever considered something like this? It could use the facilities of the rural post offices that it has built and maintained for so many years to deliver government services which are currently offered by the various departments, such as Canada Employment Centres, unemployment insurance, the income security programs, which are also being centralized. Why not create itinerant offices on a part-time basis in some of those rural post offices which Canada Post is now trying to unload? Why not use these facilities to deliver federal government services directly to the people where they are, rather than having the people who live in rural Canada travel miles and miles to get government services?

June 18, 1992

That is the thinking we on this side of the House would like to see adopted in changes to the Canada Post Corporation and in modernizing and making contemporary this very fine and very important institution.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in listening to the member opposite describe what he would like to see done with Canada Post, as he addresses what is in Bill C-73 before us tonight, it sounds as if he wants Canada Post to be run the same way it was being run 25 years ago.
We know that we had a corporation then that had a lot of complaints. When I came into this House in 1984, over half the complaints I received were all related to Canada Post. I can tell my hon. friend those complaints have diminished to maybe no more than a couple in a month now.
They have given up on the government.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
No, they have not given up on the government.
Some members have mentioned the community mailboxes that have been used. They were tested and one of the test areas from 1983-1984 was in my riding at Sardis, British Columbia. I can tell you they were reasonably well received because it was not a case of the post office expanding to door to door delivery to all the new urban areas that were coming in. This was an experiment and it has proven to be very successful.
There have been times when things have not gone that smoothly, such as the replacement of the green boxes with the new superbox. It was just a couple of weeks ago I found out that the corporation had not communicated well enough with some of the citizens involved and I had to intercede on their behalf. I must say that the corporation did respond and is coming to an amicable solution to the problem we identified a couple of weeks ago.
When we come to the closure problems we have encountered in many of the rural areas, I can give examples of where it has gone very smoothly and I can give examples of where it was planned and where Canada Post Corporation has had to change their mind.
One that has gone very smoothly is at Huntingdon, British Columbia in my riding. I did not receive a single complaint from the people who were getting their mail
Government Orders
from the Huntingdon post office because Canada Post came and communicated with them and they came to an amicable solution about how they would get their mail service and it is an ongoing thing today.
Three or four years ago when the closure of the Cultus Lake post office was announced, we did not agree with it nor did the citizens there. I felt they were using the wrong reasons for closing it. The building had burned down. The post office was using a disaster as its reason for closing it down. That decision was changed and the post office has been rebuilt and to this day is servicing that area.
I can think of no better way to make sure that the employees feel a kinship to the corporation they work for than if they own a piece of the action. That is what this legislation is all about. It allows the corporation to put up to 10 per cent of the value of its assets in shares that can be sold to the employees of Canada Post. That is what is permitted in this legislation we have before us this evening.
I feel that Canada Post has made great strides in the last half dozen years that I have been closely watching them from here in Ottawa. I see how the people are reacting to Canada Post as I go back and forth to my riding. Is the corporation loved by all the citizens? No, it is not. However, I can tell hon. members that the mail is certainly coming through on a more consistent basis than it did in the past and the service is improving. We also have more outlets for people to buy their stamps, mail their parcels and get their money orders than we had when I started here.
I will be supporting this bill when it is time to vote on it.

Mr. Speaker, Bill C-73 is a phoney piece of legislation. It is bogus. It provides for the sale of 10 per cent of Canada Post to its employees.
I guess the first question Canadians should be asking is, exactly what is the government trying to achieve? What is the hidden agenda here? What prompted this move on the part of the Government of Canada? Is it simply being magnanimous on its death bed? Is it trying to redeem itself in the eyes of the 57,000 or 60,000 loyal employees of Canada Post? Exactly what is the agenda of the Conservative government?

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
Bill C-73 will allow in a very general way the Government of Canada to sell 10 per cent of the corporation to its employees. Bill C-73 does not define employee, it does not quantify the assets and liabilities of Canada Post, it does not indicate whether these shares will be transferable and if so under what conditions.
The government claims that with the sale of these shares to Canada Post employees, somehow morale will improve, somehow the post office will become more efficient, somehow services will improve to the Canadian taxpayers but it fails to explain how.
If this government was serious about making peace with Canada Post employees, it would ensure that the workers who are presently working would be working with a contract. As I understand it, the employees have been without a contract for almost three years. Canadians suffered through a veiy serious postal strike last summer. We all recall the images of senior citizens waiting out in the heat of summer to pick up their pension cheques. We are reminded of how people were unable to receive mail for an extended period of time.
This government ought to make peace with its employees rather than trying to hoodwink them and Canadians into believing that somehow this legislation will improve service and morale.
As I indicated, this bill does not provide specifics. One thing is clear. This government is trying in a very surreptitious fashion to privatize completely Canada Post. We on this side of the House, the Liberal Party, vehemently oppose the privatization of Canada Post. It is a public service and therefore it should be in public hands. One should not make a profit, we believe, in providing service to Canadians. It would be easy for Canada Post to make significant profits. It made profits in a few years. Last year it lost $100 million. It blames that loss on the strike. Yes, it is possible for Canada Post to make profit but at what expense, at what cost?
Post offices are being closed. A significant number of Canadians have to walk to supermailboxes in order to collect their mail when a great number of others are able to get door to door delivery. It is possible to create a profit at the end of the year but one could only do so by
either increasing the cost of sending a letter or a parcel or by cutting back services.
We believe that this is a first step toward privatization. It gives the government the authority to privatize 10 per cent of the corporation for now. One should point out that even though "selling shares of Canada Post", those who purchase those shares would have no voting rights at all. They would have no say in the running of the corporation.
Surely if the government was sincere and honest and desirous of having its Canada Post employees work closely with management in improving Canada Post, it would be selling these shares with the right to vote and the right to participate in the decision-making of the corporation.
Thank God we are on the eve of a general election campaign because if we gave that bunch across the way any more time, they would even sell this building here, the House of Commons, to the highest bidder. They have proceeded in the last eight years to privatize all kinds of different institutions. If given the opportunity, they would privatize Canada Post. That is their agenda. In fact there was a Conservative report that was brought forward a number of years ago that indicated quite clearly the intention of the government to privatize. Why would someone want to buy Canada Post? Why would a group of individuals with a lot of money want to buy Canada Post? They would want to buy Canada Post if they were able to turn a profit.
The question then becomes should the delivery of mail, should postal service in Canada create profit? It seems to me that providing a service and making a profit at times are diametrically opposed. If you are interested in keeping the price of a postage stamp as low as possible and keeping service as high as possible, then you are not going to make wheelbarrows full of money at the end of the road. It does not make sense. If you privatize, if that is the intent of the government, which I believe it is, at the end of road the buyers of Canada Post will want to increase profit. We believe on this side of the House that can only be achieved by hiking up the price of a stamp or cutting back on service.
June 18, 1992

So it is conceivable that in the not too distant future there will be no such thing as door-to-door mail delivery. Not just people living in new subdivisions, but everyone in Canada will have to walk to the end of the street, key in hand, to collect their mail from a supermailbox.
I do not believe that Canadians want that. I do not believe that senior citizens want to or will be prepared to walk to the end of the street or walk a number of blocks to a supermailbox. I am afraid if the government continues on the path it has embarked upon, the inevitable result will be a cutback in service.
I do not know when we are going to have that debate. Perhaps it will take place during the general election campaign in the not too distant future, the debate over whether Canada Post ought to be privatized. We know the position of the government and it will have to justify and argue its position in the general election campaign. It will have to explain to Canadians why it wants to diminish the postal service, why it wants to privatize the postal service in Canada.
I believe that Canadians will send a very clear message to this government that they will not accept the privatization of this very essential instrument and institution in Canada that has served to unite this country from one coast to the other.
This government, as I indicated previously, during the course of its two mandates has proceeded to privatize a number of Crown corporations. It will be recalled that one of the first moves of the 1984 Conservative government was to do away with the Foreign Investment Review Agency. The government made it clear back then that there was a huge for sale sign out on the front lawn of Parliament Hill.
Again this is part of that agenda which the government has been discharging over the last number of years. We know, if given the opportunity, it would bring in legislation for the complete privatization of Canada Post.
In closing, might I again say that the Liberal Party opposes this bill. We opposed it at first reading; we will oppose it here at second reading; we will oppose it at committee. We believe it is a fraudulent piece of legislation. It is dishonest legislation because the govem-
Govemment Orders
ment really has not indicated what the purpose of it is in a straightforward manner.
We know that the employees of Canada Post have seen right through it from the moment the minister made his announcement that he was going to sell 10 per cent of the corporation to the employees. The first reaction of the employees was to ask: "Who in the heck are you trying to kid?"
I urge hon. members opposite to realize the writing is on the wall, to realize that they have a few short months left of political life here in the House of Commons of Canada, to come to their senses and to vote against this nonsensical piece of legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I do not intend to speak long. I will be very brief. I only want to make about five points.
The first point I want to make is that Canada Post is totally mismanaged. It is full of neo-Conservative ideologues who think they are running some sort of modem corporation and have no idea how to run it.
Based on your background in business?

No, based on my understanding of humanity and based on seeing what is happening in this country. I invite the Solicitor General to listen to this. The Conservative government could fall not on free trade and all the other big issues such as the Constitution, which it should fall on, but it is going to fall on an issue like the post office and I will tell you why.
The post office is a symbol to Canadians. When you go to a small town on the prairies or a small town in my riding, you see a Canada Post office and it means something to people. It was a symbol of Canada. This Conservative government has taken this symbol and destroyed it. People understand that, especially the people in the small rural areas where it has been devastating to these towns.
In my area it has moved from a perfectly good post office where there was good service and good wages for people to this low-wage clerk, Mac's Milk, 7-Eleven stuff in which mail is sometimes thrown around or lost. There is very little security. People try and do their best but they are $5 an hour clerks rather than people who really wanted to do that job and their priority job was the post office.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
I said bad management. The government missed the boat. Look over in Europe and in Britain specifically where Canada Post could have got into the area of telecommunications. It is into courier services, but not really into it the way it could have been. It could have built a modern communications system building on the basis of the Canada post office which was a symbol and a great institution in Canada and a government organization. Instead, it threw it away.
Canada Post has terrible labour relations. It is 19th century labour relations in this outfit. It deals badly with other people. It deals badly when I deal with it as a member of Parliament.
We have a situation in this country where everybody pays the same for a stamp. We all pay taxes equally and yet some people have door-to-door delivery of mail and other people do not. That is not fair and that is not equality.
New subdivisions have these post boxes. I spent months trying to get one of these post boxes moved from the front of a person's house who was getting all kinds of people coming by his house to pick up the mail. I had a lot of trouble with Canada Post.
Canada Post has bad labour relations, poor management and very little view of the future. It has this kind of blinding neo-Conservative philosophy.
Do you know something? This government will spend millions of dollars on the 125th anniversary of Canada and all the propaganda about what a great country it is. We do have a great country but look what makes it a great country: good medicare, good social services, national radio and television like the CBC. We used to have a railway system in this country and we had a post office that we could be proud of. It was a symbol in every little town in Canada.
The government could have modernized by keeping the structure of what was known as the post office. I say to this government that it is going to be defeated on issues like this.
Government has dismantled the Canadian postal system. It has this terrible system now with increased costs for stamps, with very little good delivery. The result is a national institution has been destroyed. It has the gall to come to this Parliament and bring in this bill to do this phoney privatization of share scheme.
If you want to deal with your workers go and have good labour relations. Be honest and straightforward with the workers and restore the post office to the Canadian institution that it once was.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak on the main motion. While I did speak earlier today it was on the amendment and I spoke having recently discussed some difficulties we have in the business of compensation for fisher persons and plant workers in my riding and indeed this is going to be endemic in Newfoundland and Labrador within a matter of days.
I want to get back to the issue of the post office. I want to go back to 1988 when I was first elected. I have said this many times. I have 260 communities in my riding. Not one is even semi-urban; they are all rural. The largest is a town of about 6,500 to 7,000 people. I have about 10 towns that range in population from 3,000 to 6,000. In the remaining, the populations vary from about 100 to 500, basically no large populations, so essentially it is a totally rural district.
When I was campaigning, you could leave one of these communities and travel across the island of Newfoundland, not on a passenger train but on a CN system. You could ship freight by train that ran across the island. You could visit any of these communities. In each of those communities there was a fabric of this country which the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam talked about as did my friend from Toronto, the hon. member for York South-Weston. In practically every one of these 260 communities there was a small building with a red sign on it that gave the name of the town, gave the postal code and flew a Canadian flag.
In each of those buildings people would gather to pick up their mail and to talk. Senior citizens used to go and get assistance with applications for various pensions. The postmaster or the postmistress in each of these small post offices-in fact, in one case it was in the basement of a house-were always receptive to people in trouble.
Often it had very little to do with the postal system or any difficulties with anything to do with the post office. It had to do with it being the building with the Canadian flag that was a representation of the fabric of the country and the presence of the federal government. It was where people could go if all else failed and talk to the person in charge of that postal unit. They knew they would get help.

In times of trouble and in times of great anxiety like we are going through right now particularly in my province, particularly in my riding, I cannot begin to describe what a source of relief that is, just to go and communicate or commiserate with somebody having the same problem.
Members on the opposite side would say: "That's not the purpose of the post office". I would have to agree. I could not sell the post office changes or my reluctance to accept these changes and the reluctance of my constituents on the basis of what I have just talked about. I can on the basis of the service that it gives to the individuals.
Bill C-21 tremendously altered the unemployment insurance system to the point where it was not in the favour of those people I represent in this House. With the exception of that bill and the very unpopular move to introduce the goods and services tax at the time when the economy was about to break into a recession and the government knew it but went ahead anyway, this is the third most despicable, trouble-creating and troublesome move the government has made.
Why has it been that way? Because it causes jobs to be lost.
The facts are very stark. In 1986 Canada Post had a 10-year plan that was to close 5,221 rural post offices,
10,000	jobs, 83 per cent of those belonged to women, and this government talks about jobs for women, fair play for women.
As I stand in this House tonight, over 1,000 of those rural post offices have been closed and the plan proceeds to continue until I suppose the last of the 5,221 doors is shut.
Now we cannot travel across Newfoundland. We cannot go to Sydney and get a train and travel to the rest of the country because the train system is gone. We cannot go to the post office with the little red sign and the Canadian flag because that is being shut down. Practically every other institution that people knew and cherished and lived by is being shut down. Jobs are being lost.
Government Orders
So when I hear there is a bill to do with Canada Post I get very excited and think this is a bill to change all this around. This is a bill to right all these wrongs for the people in Hare Bay, Shearstown, countless communities in my riding. I thought it was great. I was going to have a good look at this bill because everything was going to be made right.
I look at Bill C-73 and what do I see? I do not see anything that makes me happy at all. I am not about to sit down tonight, write all my constituents and tell them that all the problems of the post office are about to be solved. In fact it is going to make the situation a little worse.
In the middle of this gigantic and enormous closedown of 5,221 rural post offices and 10,000 jobs, we are now told that the government wants to sell 10 per cent of Canada Post Corporation to the employees.
That in itself sounds pretty harmless I guess, but the problem is the employees do not think this is a good idea. Why would one want to sell something to somebody when they do not want to buy it? Why would one want to do that? It is bad enough to sell something to somebody who wants to buy it, but when they not want to buy it there must be a reason for doing it.
The head of the union himself asked why post office workers want to support the efforts of Don Lander to eliminate their jobs and attack their union. Why would they buy into an organization that was doing in their jobs? It does not make a lot of sense to me.
The bill itself does not talk at all about any of the problems of Canada Post Corporation. To read the bill one would think that everything was rosy, everybody was fine, all the post offices were operating and all the customers were happy. Tbming to customers, I thought Canada Post existed to give service to the customers. But now I find out it is for another reason. If they are going to sell something eventually-I suppose this is the first step to privatizing Canada Post-somebody who is going to buy it is going to want to make a profit.
I am not going to buy a business just for the sake of buying it. I want to make a profit. Is the name of the

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
game for Canada Post to make a profit, or is it to service the public? I would suggest it is to service the public.
It is like saying that we have a great armed force but we want to make money on it. We want it to defend the country but we want to make money on it. How ridiculous a statement that is. I would submit to the House that the same pertains to wanting to make a profit out of service to the customers of Canada Post.
When you confuse your aim in doing something in this world you always end up mucking it up. I think this is what has happened to Canada Post, and this bill is going to make it even foggier.
No matter how much my colleagues and I try-and we have discussed this-we cannot find anything in this bill that makes us happy. We cannot find anything in this bill that builds up any kind of warmth in our stomachs and in our hearts.
Before I sit down I have to say that I am sure some hon. members on the government side must find some of the detail in this bill somewhat difficult to take sitting down. I suppose they will be standing up pretty soon, but I will feel sorry for them when they get up vote. Some of them might think of the constituents they have and the complaints they have had about closing down and tinkering with rural post offices. Some of them may not even be around when we vote on this subject. I would not blame them.
We have a bill that does not address the problems with Canada Post that people have realized since 1986. It exacerbates them. On that basis alone my party cannot support this bill. Certainly when my time comes the bill will not be getting my vote.

Mr. Speaker, I intend to speak for only a couple of minutes because I already made, I hope, an eloquent denunciation of the bill during consideration of the hoist motion.
I want to add information that has come to me in the last half hour from those who have been watching this debate on television. It demonstrates the arrogance of Canada Post that has conned the government into introducing this legislation as a further step toward privatization.
The very day we are debating second reading and approving in principle this bill, Canada Post is taking yet another step to devalue Canada Post and the service it is providing Canadians. Starting this weekend, right across Canada, Canada Post is going to stop processing the mails on the weekend. It is going to a five-day week so a letter mailed on Friday will not be processed until the following Monday or Ttiesday, adding yet a further delay to the service in Canada. Even if the employees turn up for work on the weekend they will be put to other tasks than the processing of the mail.
There are problem after problem after problem with Canada Post. Each of us in our own constituencies have heard them: lack of personalized response, an attitude in favour of the corporate customers that want to mail junk mail, not the individual homeowners who receive the mail, the citizens of this country. There are impenetrable labour relations' problems.
Rather than try to go along with the government's ambitions of privatizing Canada Post, the time has come that there be in every constituency in Canada an effort to develop virtually a royal commission at the constituency level.
In my riding starting next week we are going to pull together those who have come forward with various complaints about the service of Canada Post, those who have complained about having to go to Vancouver to talk to anybody about a complaint, those who complain and quite properly about the kind of service they have been receiving from Canada Post, the employees, and the union. We will pull them together to begin to see if we can develop an alternative to the kind of service we have been getting from Canada Post so that after the next election there will be in place a whole new approach to providing service in Canada, and not just the privatization of this once vital service in this country.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was not going to speak but the very careful suggestion that the hon. member for Victoria, which I thought was an excellent suggestion about Canada Post, brought a thought to my mind that I felt I had to share with the government. Perhaps the Solicitor General in assisting his colleague, the minister responsible for Canada Post, the government House leader, who I think spends very little time frankly on his Canada Post responsibilities-

June 18, 1992

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Come on, Peter. Leave him alone.

He is busy doing his House leadership job and I recognize that. It is tough for him to get time so perhaps the Solicitor General could help him out on that.
I want to make a suggestion on how Canada Post could save money. Maybe it has already implemented this but I am not sure. It used to produce an audit. It hired an auditing firm. I think it was Peat Marwick Thome, but I do not want to damage the name of this good firm. I am not suggesting that there is anything wrong with Peat Marwick Thome, but it used to provide this audit. If that is not the firm that did it, then my memory has slipped. Members on all sides of the House I am sure received this audit which said that 98 per cent of the mail was delivered on time. It was one of the great things because it did not give the parameters. They said they would check mail that was postmarked on such and such a date to see if it was delivered within two days. If it got there within two days, which was the designated deadline, then it was delivered 98 per cent of the time. Their figures were very impressive.
I have not seen one of these audits lately. Either the figures have gone sour or else the auditors realized they were being set up for a con job by Canada Post. This is what happened. I discovered this myself after a bit of investigating. If you mail your letter after 3 p.m. on any day it doesn't get postmarked until the next day even if you mail it at the post office.
Go and check it out. Go to the post office and try to register a letter and get it postmarked after 3 p.m. It cannot be done. Registered or postmarked, they will not stamp for the day it is mailed if you mail it after 3 p.m.
Get up earlier in the morning.

The Solicitor General says to get up earlier in the morning. That is the way he treats Canadians. Get up earlier and then your mail will get postmarked in time. If you do not mail it before 3 p.m. then it is postmarked the next day.
What does the auditor do? He looks at the postmark and says: "Oh, this wasn't mailed today on June 18 because it is postmarked June 19". If I mail my letter tonight it will be postmarked tomorrow. If I mailed it at 3.01 p.m. it would be postmarked tomorrow. You put the
Government Orders
mail in the mailbox down the street on the comer at 10 a.m. Collection is at 2 p.m. and it does not get to the post office till after 3 p.m. It is considered as having been mailed the next day.
It may take three or four days to get delivered, but according to the audit it has taken from the date of the postmark, so it is counted as having been mailed that day. What a con job. That is management. That is Tory mismanagement of the post office in this country. It is a disgrace. They are trying to hoodwink Canadians by this policy.
The hon. member can wag her finger to her heart's content. I will not be intimidated by this kind of tactic. I know what is going on and so do Canadians. They are being hoodwinked by this government into believing that Canada Post is providing superb service. Look at the ads they used to run. Does the hon. member for Bonavista- Trinity-Conception remember these ads?
Yes, I do. Who paid for them?

You would get them in the weekly newspapers. Who paid for the ads? It was Canada Post. Canada Post must have taken a loss that year. It ran full page ads with the results of this phoney audit. I have no doubt the audit was correct as far as it went, but then it excluded all this evidence of the non-postmarking of the envelopes. It was unbelievable.
That is the kind of thing that causes Canadians to lose confidence in the government because they feel they are being hoodwinked and bamboozled at every turn.
That is exactly what this bill will do. I fear for the employees of Canada Post who somehow think it is a good investment to buy these shares. These are non-voting shares in a company which is 90 per cent controlled by the Government of Canada that is trying to squeeze every cent it can out of this company.
It is a sad commentary when a government introduces a bill like this. I am pleased that the Liberal members in this House are going to be able to condemn this bill and oppose it.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Is the House ready for the question?
Question.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
Is it the pleasure of the House to adopt the motion?

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
Agreed.
No.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: All those in favour of the motion will please say yea.
Yea.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole

Nay.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole

On division.
Motion agreed to, bill read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
The House proceeded to the consideration of Bill C-46, an act respecting contraventions of federal enactments, as reported (with amendments) from a legislative committee.

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. There have been discussions among the parties prior to the move that I am about to make, so it shall not come as a surprise to anybody.
On behalf of the government I wish to point out that clause 66 of Bill C-46 would abolish the right of the Crown to refuse to issue a passport or to revoke it as a consequence of a charge or conviction under the Contraventions Act. This clause would affect Her Majesty's prerogatives.
His Excellency the Governor General has been informed of the purport of this bill and has given his consent, as far as Her Majesty's prerogatives are affected, to the consideration by Parliament of the bill, that Parliament may do therein as it thinks fit.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
I have a ruling to make on Bill C-46.
There are two motions in amendment set down on the Notice Paper for the report stage of Bill C-46, an act respecting contraventions of federal enactments, both in the name of the hon. member for Niagara Falls.
Motions Nos. 1 and 2 are grouped for debate and a vote on Motion No. 1 will apply to Motion No. 2.
I will now proceed with Motions Nos. 1 and 2 in the House.

Mr. Speaker, I am seeking unanimous consent to put the motions in the place of the hon. member for Niagara Falls because of his annual meeting this evening. I believe there were discussions and it was agreed that I could stand in his place.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Is there unanimous consent?
As far as our party is concerned, we would agree.
I agree.

speakeroldname: Mr. Blaine A. Thacker (for Mr. Nicholson) moved:
speechtext:
Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-46 be amended in Clause 8
(a)	by striking out, in the English version, line 16 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"purposes of this Act;"
(b)	by striking out line 18 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"ceedings under this Act; and
(/) providing for subparagraph 18(6)(iii), section 20, subsection 21(2) and sections 24 and 27 to have effect or to cease to have effect as if they had come into force or been repealed, as the case may be, in the parts of Canada that are specified in the regulations.";
(c)	by adding, immediately after line 4 at page 5, the following: "(8) Subsection (1) is amended by striking out the word "and" at the end of paragraph (e) thereof, by adding the word "and" at the end of paragraph (d) thereof and by repealing paragraph (f) thereof."
Motion No. 2.
That Bill C-46 be amended in Clause 86
(a)	by striking out line 34 at page 39 and substituting the following therefor:

He said: Mr. Speaker, these technical amendments flow from the legislative committee hearings and would allow a pilot project to be undertaken regarding the non-resident defendant provisions of the legislation.
Clause 27 permits the non-resident defendant to plead not guilty by mailing in submissions. Clause 24 permits the non-resident defendant to plead not guilty with representations by mail.
Several jurisdictions have expressed concerns about the administrative difficulty which could be encountered in bringing these into operation. Some jurisdictions would like to see the results of a pilot project before the non-resident defendant provisions are implemented more broadly across the country.
The proposed amendment would allow this aspect of the ticketing program to be tested in specific locations, thus giving us the flexibility to determine whether these sections can be reasonably affected.
The principle of pilot projects to test these provisions was put forward and accepted at the committee hearings, and the proposed motions seek to ensure that pilot projects can be set up in particular locations which have been identified in co-operation with the provinces as suitable areas for proper program testing.

Mr. Speaker, the member for Lethbridge has made a good point. While I think it would be our hope that such a process could be done, it is fair to say that we really do not know the results.
Whereas the various jurisdictions have expressed concern as to this process and the concept is relatively new, a pilot project is a very prudent way to go.

Mr. Speaker, I would agree to this amendment as well. We did discuss it in committee but not at great length. I was not really aware that there would be a pilot project. However I must say-and I will say this in my speech at third reading-I was impressed by the public servants that came before the committee. They were very straightforward with us.
I am going to give them the benefit of the doubt. They need a pilot project. I think we should give them that leeway.
My friend, the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys, would agree with me that we had a very good legislative committee, a very straightforward group of civil servants who presented things and did not duck any
Government Orders
of the questions. When they did not know the answer they told us so. It was a real pleasure.
On behalf of the New Democratic Party, as our party's justice critic, I would agree to these amendments. We can deal with them tonight.

speakeroldname: Mr. Mayer (for the Minister of Transport) moved
speakerposition: Minister of Western Economic Diversification; Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)
speechtext: that the bill be read the third time and passed.

Mr. Speaker, I want to say a few words about this bill. My colleague, the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, said that he was very impressed by the public servants on this and I was as well. I do not know if it was because they had all the answers or because they were so calm. I knew they really believed in the bill. They were speaking so effortlessly and had all of the answers and I felt my first instincts on this were correct, that this is a good bill and that there is nothing here of great substance with which to find fault.
There are two aims in this bill. One is to decriminalize approximately 3,500 offences by creating the option for the enforcement officer to issue a ticket to an offender rather than pursuing a summary conviction or an indictment and to free up the court's time by eliminating the need to hear these minor offences.
That is not to say that in the regulations right now, 12 departments, agencies or groups in the federal service everyone has to plead guilty. What it does mean is that if someone is charged and ticketed, under the regulations designated under this bill, they can plead guilty and pay their fine. They do not have to appear in court. They can send in their money as is the case in other instances in which this is being used in the provinces.

Government Orders
That is not to say that the ticketing officer or the officer making the charge has to instigate the charge with a ticket. The officer can still bring a charge through a summary conviction or an indictable offence.
That is the choice of the officer. That does not mean that the person so charged has to plead guilty or does not get a chance to plead his case. He can and has that opportunity. What it does do is free up a good deal of the court's time. The process of having to come to court to pay these fines is no longer necessary. It makes considerable sense. It makes a great deal of sense.
The government has said that this bill will be revenue neutral. It will be better than revenue neutral because although the process will be revenue neutral, we will save a lot of the court's time. This will be a financial benefit to the justice system.
I feel that there is a possibility in this bill that we can expand to other regulations. We must be very careful to state here that this deals with regulatory offences. It does not deal with offences under the Criminal Code. That is very important. Proceedings under the Criminal Code will proceed as they have in the past. This deals with regulatory offences.
There has been some suggestion by gun owners that this is an attempt to perhaps circumvent their rights and that is not true. This has nothing to do with gun control. It has nothing to do with the Criminal Code. It has to do with straightforward, regulatory offences.
The one concern that people could have is that the regulations to be designated under this bill are through Order in Council. That is, the Parliament of Canada or the committees do not designate what regulations are to apply. The regulations to apply are designated by Order in Council. That means the government designates.
The concern is that what will happen is that very important and weighty regulations will be brought under this bill such as strong environmental regulations to stop the pollution of our streams and of our air. What will happen is that these companies will lobby the government to include these offences under this bill. The
reason is that the maximum fine under this bill is $1,000. You can have any regulation apply but the maximum fine is $1,000. You cannot fine anyone more than $1,000. If you are a young offender, the maximum is $100.
You could see that a corporation which had polluted a river or severely polluted the atmosphere or otherwise caused environmental problems would be very pleased to have its offence handled under this act as a regulatory offence with a maximum fine of $1,000.
This is maybe a little exaggerated. It may be going too far to say that the government would do a thing like this. I think that may be true but it is going to mean that we as members of Parliament are going to have to watch this very carefully.
This bill does have the support of all of the attorneys general in Canada. They seem quite content that this is going to be a major step forward. As I have mentioned, the Department of Justice is only administering this bill. There are no Criminal Code offences and the regulations apply to other departments and agencies.
I would also like to point out that this bill is not a new idea. It is an idea that has been promoted in the past. The Law Reform Commission in 1976 came forward with a document which set out this idea and promoted it strongly. That was 16 years ago. It took 10 years for this government to adopt the thinking that this may be a good way to proceed with offences such as speeding in your boat out on the lake for instance. We have it now, six years later, as proposed legislation.
I want to point out that here is a tremendous example of the value of the Law Reform Commission of Canada. This government doing away with the Law Reform Commmission as a result of its recent budget makes Canada the only country in the British Commonwealth, other than Zimbabwe and Bangladesh, without a Law Reform Commission. It is the only government in Canada that does not have a Law Reform Commission. Now that Quebec is instituting legislation to set up a Law Reform Commission, all the provinces have Law Reform Commissions. A federal country with a federal system of government depriving the provinces of access to this creative legal thinking without the federal government having this is just preposterous to say the least.

I would like to end this very important point of doing away with the Law Reform Commission by suggesting that this is not the only idea that the Law Reform Commission germinated. We have read citings in various court cases. I think 44 cases of the Supreme Court of Canada cite the documentation and the legal thinking of the Law Reform Commission, not to mention considerable articles and legal books on various points of law. Most recently in the legislative committee on this bill doing away with the Law Reform Commission, various groups came before the committee to plead with the government to change its mind in doing away with this very important organization.
If you could say that one group was more effective than another, it was the multicultural groups in Canada. There has been some very good work done by the Law Reform Commission on multiculturalism and the law which finished its first draft and was supposed to be the subject of meetings with the multicultural community four days after the budget was tabled. However, the budget was tabled and those meetings were cancelled. We do not know what is going to happen to that very good piece of legal thinking. Whether it will ever see the light of day no one knows. The thinking among the members of the multicultural community is no. This whole effort and this very important document will go to waste which is in itself a very unfortunate thing.
I also want to say that this has been a very important project on behalf of the member for Parry Sound-Mus-koka who has been very instrumental in pushing the government to bring this legislation forward. I feel he should be credited for the work he has done.
This is, as I say, a step forward. I think we are going to have to watch the way matters proceed with respect to this legislation. One of the ways is certainly with respect to the pilot project which my colleague, the member for Lethbridge, has mentioned, and also with respect to what regulations are brought forward under this bill.
As my colleague, the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, has stated as well, I think it might be important
Government Orders
to bring the new regulations that may be applied under this bill before the House of Commons before they are actually included under this legislation.
I want to say that I think this bill should pass. In my opinion, it is a step forward and it is going to be a benefit.

Mr. Speaker, I rise as the NDP justice critic to speak on this bill, one in a long series of justice bills that we have been debating in this House.
This is a ticketing scheme for minor regulatory offences. Currently, just to explain how the law works, a person wishing to plead guilty to an offence, even one as minor as picking flowers on federal property or speeding in an inlet or lake, must appear in court. Even in that person's absence, if the person does not appear, a trial must be held and witnesses must be heard. It is an expensive and time-consuming process.
We have an alternative method of doing things. We have ticketing offences in the provinces, traffic tickets for example. Bill C-46 proposes a ticketing scheme for minor regulatory offences and was designed primarily for the following reasons.
First of all, it decriminalizes minor offences against federal laws and regulations. As my friend pointed out, not the Criminal Code but other federal laws and regulations. Second, it avoids the need for a court appearance when a ticket is not contested. Third, it encourages improved enforcement. I might add as a Scotsman it is probably going to end up a little cheaper.
Bill C-46 does not create new offences. It only changes procedures that deal with existing minor federal offences. We are told that the government expects there will be over 400,000 tickets issued in the first year this scheme comes into effect. These fines will be paid. They will go into general revenue and so they will not be an additional means of raising funds, say for Agriculture Canada or Environment Canada. Savings will be realized as a result of a decrease in demand placed upon our courts. It seems like a good idea financially.

June 18, 1992
Government Orders
I spoke on the bill in the House at second reading and I will not repeat that speech. It was on Monday, April 6,
1992.	In case members want some bedtime reading tonight, they can get Hansard and have a look at it.
One point I did make in the speech and I will reiterate was that this idea which we all agree now is a good idea and is going to save the government money and streamline the judicial process was first introduced in 1976 by the Law Reform Commission of Canada. That is the same Law Reform Commission the member previously said the government is going to abolish.
It was doing good things. This is another argument to buttress the opposition's point of view that it really was not too intelligent to get rid of the Law Reform Commission of Canada because it advanced some of these ideas that ultimately became law. Here is a perfect example.
I should say also that I was impressed with the way the civil service and the committee brought forward the bill in a straightforward way and said when they did not know the answers that they did not know the answers. That is why I am prepared to agree. I was prepared and did agree to a pilot project in this matter.
Mark Berlin of the justice department notes that all provinces have a similar program in place. It is probably a result of provincial representations that the federal department is taking the initiative.
They did hint at a few things like using credit cards, Visa cards, and various ways to pay fines. I do not know how that is going to work. I told them not to get too fancy. Look at how the provincial traffic schemes work and try to follow that. Do not get too fancy or you will end up like the post office.
I will end with two wishes. As the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys pointed out, a lot of this law, as many laws, is in the regulations. I hope the regulations will see the light of day. I hope the department will publish them, show them widely, so that we can change them and make them better.
Finally, my last wish is this. I know it is a bit late to do this now but I have a bill in front of the House called the Plain Language Act in which I have asked that the government draft bills in plain language, plain English or plain French. It is too much to expect us to speak in plain language in the House but the government could draft in plain language. The government might want to have a
look at future bills, especially the regulations under this bill, and draft them in plain language so Canadians can understand exactly what is meant by the regulations. This would be a good bill to begin with.
I have talked about plain language, about open and competent regulations and about how important it is that this bill pass because it is overdue. It will make a better process and I hope a cheaper process for Canadians. Having finally got to the end of a long series of justice bills, I am pleased to sit down and to shut up. In plain English I say I am finished speaking and I hope this bill will pass.

Mr. Speaker, I will not repeat everything that has been said vis-a-vis the bill, but I want to stand on behalf of the Minister of Justice and the parliamentary secretary to express their deep appreciation for the co-operation that they have received and the very good scrutiny that this bill received by the justice committee.
I must say with respect to the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys and the member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, I feel like we almost live together, because we have done so many bills over the last while. We have become almost like brothers in a way, not to say that there are not some very sharp differences, as you might guess in a family, Mr. Speaker.
Having been through Bill C-49, the sexual offences bill; Bill C-17, the gun control bill, and then the gun control regulations that we just finished off today, as well as bills that the others have done on terrorism, jury trials, and then acting for the distinguished Solicitor General on Bill C-36 the Parole Act, these have all been huge bills.
It is too bad in a way that our constituents could not see the enormous good work that is done by members on all sides of the House at the committee level. Once the television lights are turned off and we can put ourselves around a problem, we can usually come up with some very sensible solutions. We only go mad, Mr. Speaker, when the television goes on us and we have to put on a show it seems. I guess that is just the way it always will be.
I also I want to express on the record to our long-time colleague, the distinguished member for Parry Sound- Muskoka, who has been a member in this House for many years that this bill was pushed by him over all of those years and he deserves a lot of credit for it.
June 18, 1992

Mr. Speaker, this is good public law.
Motion agreed to, bill read the third time and passed.
