speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Richardson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of TVansport):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
subtopic: AIRPORT TRANSFER (MISCELLANEOUS MATTERS) ACT MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank hon. members for that consent.
It was not long ago we discussed the predecessor bill, Bill C-15, which essentially set the basis for employee protection benefits associated with any lease or sale of federal airports. Bill S-ll is really a fine-tuning bill.
Government Orders
As the House will be aware, the process of devolution to the local airport authority has been long and involved for the first group of airports. Along the way we learned quite a few things.
Since we last discussed this issue, we have signed transfer agreements with four local airport authorities in Montreal, Vancouver, Edmonton, and Calgary. This bill represents some additional legislative requirements to complete the process.
Essentially it maintains the status quo regarding federal income tax; it sets out the local airport authority's powers for seizure and detention of aircraft in the event of non-payment of fees with due reference to the courts.
As well the bill addresses the qualification of investments and the connection with the transfer of the airports to local airport authorities.
Finally the bill makes it mandatory for the local airport authorities to respect additional provisions of the Official Languages Act, namely Part V, the language of work, and Part VI, equal participation of English or French speaking Canadians for leased airports within the designated areas as defined by the Official Languages Act.
It came to our attention after Bill C-15 was already in process that in order to ensure the continuation of the status quo with regard to payment of income tax, a legislative amendment was necessary and hence the clause in this bill.
I should perhaps also expand on why clause 11 is required. Prior to June 1, 1992 federal trust, loan and insurance companies as well as federal pension funds were permitted to make investments accordingly to the legal for life rules. One investment described by the rules was a mortgage on a leasehold interest.
Since the concept of leasehold does not exist under Quebec civil law, mortgages on airport land would not be eligible investments. This could have made it difficult for the Montreal local airport authority to obtain long-term financing.
As of June 1,1992 the date of the coming into force of the new financial institution statutes, the legal for life rules were removed. Now any investment can be subject to a "prudent portfolio requirement". However federally regulated pension funds continue to be subject to the legal for life rules, but will be moved to the prudent portfolio concept in the future.

Government Orders
Therefore, the proposed clause 11 will ensure that there are no obstacles for pension fund investments in mortgages on airport land.
I believe the bill is pretty well self-explanatory, and I would like to close my remarks now by recommending it to you, and asking that Bill S-11 be given your consideration in as expeditious a manner as possible.
I thank my hon. colleagues on both sides of the House for their great co-operation in this matter in particular and for the their support of the local airport authorities in general.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
subtopic: AIRPORT TRANSFER (MISCELLANEOUS MATTERS) ACT MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not a member who likes to rise and say I told you so, but of course the Solicitor General, who I believe was Minister of Transport when this bill was originally introduced in the House, the divestiture bill as we called it, I think it was Bill C-15 might want to learn something from this little exercise because this is a case where unfortunately it shows up the problems that occur when the government does not listen to the opposition in this House.
The government would not have to introduce this bill tonight if it had listened to the opposition when Bill C-15 was before the House. I do not want to unfairly malign the Solicitor General but I suspect he was Minister of Transport at the time. Perhaps we will have true confessions later tonight.
What happened on that occasion and I am sure you, Mr. Speaker, will remember it because you I expect were listening to the debate and probably noticing how right we were when this bill was discussed in June 1991.
Time and again, members of the opposition rose and said that they could not understand why the government was not having the Official Languages Act apply in certain particulars to this bill. I have a string of members who rose and spoke on this issue. They were the hon. members for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, Hamilton West, Gander-Grand Falls and Ottawa-Vanier. The hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier was particularly explicit in
his explanation as to why Parts V, VI and VII of the Official Languages Act ought to apply to this particular bill.
He spoke eloquently and at length pleading with the government. Let me quote his words from page 998 of Hansard: "I intend to explain to the House the impact of this oversight or this government decision not to include Parts V, VI and VH". He gave a lengthy explanation and he went on to say:
Mr. Speaker, I simply want to say that Parts V and VI are important to us because in our opinion they deal with the most fundamental issues. That is the right of individuals, the right of Canadians to equal employment opportunities but also the right to work in federal institutions in the language of their choice. If this policy applies to Air Canada, which we know must follow all of the provisions of the Official Languages Act, I fail to see why an employee of Air Canada would be entitled to equal employment opportunities and would also be entitled to work in the language of his choice whereas an employee of a local regional or municipal authority in charge of an airport would not enjoy the same protection.
This was all said in a desperate effort to help this government out of a mess that it created. The hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier moved a motion to amend the bill. He moved:
That the motion be amended by deleting the words "be read for the third time and passed" and substituting the following therefor:
"be not now read a third time but be referred back to the legislative committee for the purpose of reconsidering clause 4 of the bill by striking out line 17 of page 2 and substituting-"
I do not need to read the rest of it, but he wanted to put the act in.
I may have maligned the former Minister of Transport because I see he spoke right after and he was Solicitor General. One can only assume that he opposed this very sensible amendment moved by my colleague the distinguished and very capable member for Ottawa-Vanier.
Here we are, almost one year later, and the government is coming back to Parliament on bended knee asking the opposition to pass the amendment we wanted the government to pass one year ago. Indeed, it wants more amendments. Many of them were the ones that were mentioned at the time.
June 18, 1992

Tax exemption has been included in this bill. My friend, the government House leader disparages the other place and speaks in uncomplimentary terms from time to time about the other place. Yet the Senate had hearings on Bill C-15. The question was asked, apparently by an officer of Transport Canada why this tax exemption was included in this bill and not in the original bill.
The answer was: "At the time we came forward with Bill C-15 there was no definitive decision from Revenue Canada whether or not under existing law they would qualify". Subsequent to the tabling of the bill, it became clear that they would not qualify under the existing legislation because authorities were a unique corporate institution". If it became evident after the tabling, why did it not fix it up?
It shows the indecent haste with which this government tries to force bills through this House. It ignores throughout the strong advice of the members of the opposition who tiy to correct the blunders that the government so obviously made in introducing the legislation.
The hon. member laughs. It would be a laughing matter if it did not cost so much money to run this House. We have a reasonable opposition here which speaks for such a brief time on almost every bill anyway. Instead of listening, the ministers flit off and go elsewhere. The members sit and laugh and ignore the remarks of the opposition, thinking they are a waste of time. It shows that our remarks are not a waste of time. If only somebody had paid attention government members would not be here today with this other bill. It would not have taken weeks getting it through the other place. This is an expensive process. Hon. members opposite laugh about it and think it is a joke. I do not think it is a joke.
Then there were the sections on seizure of aircraft. Sections 4(5) and 4(6) of the Aeronautics Act give the transport minister the power to seize and detain aircraft for non-payment of landing fees or terminal fees. Sections 9 and 10 of this new bill give the local authorities similar power.
Why was it not in the original bill? An officer of Transport Canada said: "We did not know at the time the first bill was introduced. We discovered after we did work with lawyers on the other side that it would be prudent to put it in." If we had spent a little bit of time thinking about it, there might have been some lawyers in this House who might have thought it was prudent to put it in.
Government Orders

speechtext:

Maybe the government should hire us on in the government departments. That would be a disappointment though. Then we would not get to speak in this House. We could give them some advice on how to fix these bills up, but we give them that advice freely in this House and it is freely ignored by the government.
I have to say I find it sad that in spite of the very serious efforts of at least four members during the debate in June 1991 on this bill, I believe all at third reading, and the amendment moved by the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier to rectify the blunder, the government ignored all that advice. Now, as I say, it is back here on bended knee asking us to pass this bill tonight.
Of course, having put these amendments forward on a previous occasion, we are happy to support the bill tonight and to facilitate its speedy passage in the House. subtopic: AIRPORT TRANSFER (MISCELLANEOUS MATTERS) ACT MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know we are all anxious to get this over with this evening especially on a matter where we find ourselves to be in so much agreement.
I want to add to the comments of my colleague from Kingston and the Islands. Again, it is nice that the Solicitor General is here, who was Minister of Transport at the time. The same as my colleague, we always hate to say we told you so, but in all humility, we told you so, we told you so, we told you so.
I would just like to comment on the bill itself before getting down to the particular amendments that we moved and supported in committee in March 1991. I want to comment very briefly on the purpose of the bill before us which is to amend the Airport Transfer (Miscellaneous Matters) Act, the main provisions of the bill being to continue the existing status under the new local airport authorities recognizing that this does not represent any change in moneys paid to the government; to extend to local airport authorities the same powers, procedure and detention of aircraft as currently exists in relation to major non-payment of fees; to regularize the status of various financial investments for the purposes of security; and the one I want to add a few comments on, to extend Parts V and VI of the Official Languages Act, namely language of work and equal participation

Government Orders
provisions to airports that are leased by the federal government to local airport authorities. This particular provision, Parts V and VI, does not apply to airports that would be sold in the future.
In committee on March 13, 1991 my colleague, the transport critic for the New Democratic Party, the member for Thunder Bay-Atikokan, supported at that time by the Liberal member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon and the Liberal member for York West attempted to correct the language aspect of the bill.
In committee on the date I referred to, my colleague from Thunder Bay-Atikokan in reference to the amendments which he moved at that time which now appear before us as Parts V and VI said: "The purpose of the amendment is to have all aspects of the Official Languages Act apply to these airports".
I recognized that we had testimony from all local airport authorities involved to date indicating they did not feel it was appropriate. On the other hand, yesterday we also heard testimony from the union that indicated it felt it would be important for its members. Certainly in talking with it after the meeting about this particular clause, I understand that even though its members would no longer be part of the federal Public Service, because of the expertise they will have developed whether it is in Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Montreal, or any of the other areas, they will be prime candidates for open competition within the federal Public Service.
As they move up the ladder within the local airport authority their expertise will be something that will be sought. It is to the benefit of the union's members and I think also to the local airport authorities to have staff appropriately trained in both official languages based on the existing legislation.
I realize that at this time it may only affect the local airport authority from Montreal and Mirabel but over time it may affect others. Until then it will not be an onerous condition on the western airports.
Montreal was very clear that it will have the most highly qualified bilingual staff of any place in the country and so I do not think it would be an onerous burden on it.
Following the member's comments, the member for York West said: "I would like to support the motion of Mr. Angus which is analogous to the very same amendment that we put forward as our fifth amendment".
Following that intervention, the member for Man-icouagan said: "I listened carefully to what Mr. Angus had to say. I was concerned about the same points during our public hearings. I do not believe that including Parts V and VI of the Official Languages Act would add anything at all to this bill. Only the Montreal airport authority would be bound by these sections since Montreal is at present the only bilingual district recognized by the Official Languages Act. The people of Montreal have made it very clear that they will be competing with airports on the east coast of the United States, Toronto, and elsewhere. They want to be free to conduct their affairs in the language best suited to the circumstances.
It seems to me that by including Parts V and VI of the Official Languages Act in Bill C-85 we would be putting the Montreal airport authority at a disadvantage because Montreal is the only place where these sections would apply. They would not apply to Edmonton, Calgary or Vancouver because these cities are not recognized as bilingual districts by the Official Languages Act and therefore their airport authorities would not have to comply with these conditions. I would ask the committee to consider this point. By including these two sections in Bill C-85, we would be putting Montreal's airport administration at a disadvantage".
The government side did not listen to the amendments or suggestions put forward by both representatives of the Liberal Party and of the New Democratic Party, in particular the member for Thunder Bay-Atikokan. It did not listen in committee. It did not listen to the amendments and the arguments and suggestions later put forward in the House. Now, as my colleague from Kingston and the Islands has pointed out, we have had to go through the lengthy and costly exercise of having it

come back through the other place with significant argument and study there, and back to the House here.
We, along with the Official Opposition, are granting every co-operation we can to see this matter is dealt with as expeditiously as possible in this House tonight. We are happy to do that but we do state again that we wish the government would be more sympathetic and open in future to hearing reasoned arguments based on study of the legislation and its real implications rather than simply ignoring advice coming from the opposition because it is the opposition side.
We are happy to support these amendments and hope that we do not have to do this kind of particular exercise too much more often in the future.

subtopic: AIRPORT TRANSFER (MISCELLANEOUS MATTERS) ACT MEASURE TO AMEND
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, very succinctly. I was not going to intervene in this discussion after my colleague from Kootenay had expressed those thoughts, along with my colleague from Kingston and the Islands. We on this side of the House right from the inception-I am glad that the former Minister of Transport is here-of the transfer of jurisdiction to local airport authorities supported that legislation with great enthusiasm. Many of us on this side of the House felt that the local airport authority was the only way we could compete in a global economy in so far as airport business was concerned. We were then in the process of an open skies debate. As a result, we felt that the local airport authority was a very good idea and supported it fully.
Since that time though, I have been very disappointed with the speed with which we have been able to proceed with the local airport authority in getting these airports in Canada transferred over to the proper jurisdictions. I can say, having been on that committee that my former colleague discussed, having visited with the local airport authorities in Edmonton, Calgary, Vancouver and Mirabel in the Province of Quebec, they were all enthusiastic about going along with the legislation for the local airport authority, but for some reason or other it was constantly delayed.
My concern, and the reason for getting up, Mr. Speaker, is that I know there is a very active local airport
Government Orders
authority in my riding of Thunder Bay which wants to look after and take over the airport facility. They are very keen, they are very knowledgeable. I would not want to let this opportunity go by without impressing upon our colleagues across the aisle how important it is that they proceed with this proposal with all dispatch.
I just make that message and thank you, Mr. Speaker, for the opportunity of saying that.
